PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Lump Sum Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Taxation: Lump Sum Superannuation

To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that we are concerned about any increases in taxation on lump sum superannuation because:
The Federal Government does not have a mandate to introduce these changes.
During April, the Prime Minister gave a definite assurance that the existing basis of taxation for lump sum superannuation payments would not be altered.
The proposed scheme eliminates freedom of choice, in that retirees will be forced into accepting a pension, because of prohibitive taxation levels on lump sum benefits.
The existing principle of having only 5 per cent of lump sum benefits attract taxation has been a fundamental maxim of Australian life since at least 1928.
Severe pressure will be placed on the ability of superannuation funds to maintain full C.P.I. indexation of pensions.
Retirees will be denied the present flexibility that existing legislation allows.
In many cases, lump sum payments provide the finance to obtain a standard of living not previously attainable during a working life.
The opportunity to invest a lump sum at the individual's discretion will be denied-to avoid the prohibitive taxation rate, a lump sum will have to be converted to an annuity superannuation.
Presently, an individual may invest a lump sum entirely at his own discretion, to provide a retirement income which is taxable.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should immediately without reference to a Senate standing committee, reject any legislation to increase taxation on lump sum superannuation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3, Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances amoung children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3, Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That in 1911, as part of its new responsibility for the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth accepted a binding legislative commitment to construct a railway from Adelaide to Darwin-a promise which has never been fulfilled.
The lack of essential transport links has had, and continues to have, serious consequences for the economic and social development of the Northern Territory, and indeed all of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, eight sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) (Amendment) Ordinance 1982, as contained in the Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 95 of 1982 and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed.
(2) That the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1983 No. 38 and made under the Customs Act 1901, be disallowed.
I seek leave to make a very brief statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first notice of motion concerns section 4 of the Law Reform Ordinance which appears to remove existing rights and claims with retrospective effect. The second notice of motion concerns a drafting practice which may result in legislative requirements to notify persons of appeal rights being nullified by a saving provision. In the case of the first notice of motion today is the last day on which notice may be given and in the case of the second notice of motion it is the second last day. Therefore the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances is giving notice to preserve its rights while awaiting replies from the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to correspondence from the Committee. In accordance with practice recently adopted by the Committee, I seek leave to have a fuller statement of the Committee's concerns incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
NOTICES OF DISALLOWANCE
LAW REFORM ORDINANCE AND CUSTOMS REGULATIONS
Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) (Amendment) Ordinance 1982

The purpose of this Ordinance is to exclude the estate of a deceased person from recovering damages for loss of earning capacity during the years lost to that person by his premature death. The amending Ordinance nullifies the so- called ''lost years'' decision in Fitch v. Hyde-Cates (1982) 39 A.L.R. 581, determined by the High Court on 6 April 1982.

The Committee makes no comment on the prospective operation of the amending Ordinance other than to observe that it negates a right the High Court has held to exist. The question of primary concern to the Committee, under its principles , derives from section 4 of the amending Ordinance. This section appears to make the amendment retrospective in operation, with the consequence that existing rights and existing claims are removed.

The Committee has sought the views of the Attorney-General on this matter. As today is the last day on which notice may be given, the Committee has given such notice to preserve its rights while awaiting a reply from the Attorney-General.
Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations (Amendment)

The purpose of these regulations is to waive the requirement for censorship examination of films in circumstances such as showing it at a recognised film festival. The regulations provide that the Attorney-General may approve organisations and events to benefit from the relaxation and may revoke the approval. Regulation 34 provides for an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against a decision of the Attorney-General. While Regulation 34 (3) provides that the notice:

''. . . shall include a statement to the effect that, subject to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, application may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of the decision to which the notice relates by or on behalf of a person whose interests are affected by the decision .'',
Regulation 34 (4) provides:
''(4) A failure to comply with the requirements of sub-regulation (3) in relation to a decision shall not be taken to affect the validity of the decision .''

As indicated to the Senate in November and December last year in relation to an Ordinance of the Australian Capital Territory, the Committee has had some concern that the effect of the ''saving clause'' might be to nullify the legislative provision which should ensure that notification of rights is automatically made to persons affected by decisions which may be subject to appeal. The Committee sought and received a response from the former Attorney- General on the drafting practice which has given rise to this provision. However , the Committee has now asked for the present Attorney-General's views on the matter.

As a working rule, the Committee has accepted assurances from successive Ministers administering Ordinances in which this provision has appeared that notification of appeal rights will be routinely given. In this case, however, the regulations were made under the authority of the Attorney-General, whose general comments the Committee now awaits, and therefore the Committee has given notice of disallowance to preserve its rights while the Attorney considers the matter.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANS AUSTRALIA AIRLINES AND ANSETT AIRLINES OF AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I do not think that the report of Trans Australia Airlines should pass without comment. I simply draw attention to two major features. One is that the Government has, I believe, quite properly increased the actual capital of TAA to enable its capital base and, therefore, its gearing ratio to be more appropriate to an operation of a commercial undertaking so that its figures are not likely to be, I hope, as disastrous as those disclosed in the report which has been tabled today. In fairness to TAA, it should be made abundantly clear at the start that one of the major reasons for the disastrous figures which are disclosed-whether it be a deficit of about $500,000 or just under, or whether it be what the Auditor-General says, something approaching $7m; a matter I will come to shortly-is the fact that the gearing ratio of Trans Australia Airlines is a huge amount of debt and very little capital. When there is a huge gearing ratio, the exposure to debt and, therefore, to interest rates must leave one in a position where the results appear, in comparison with a company which is geared on a private sector basis, to be extremely bad indeed.

The second point is that, notwithstanding that fact, the results must cause alarm to everyone who is interested in the operation of the airlines in Australia and in an efficient system of air transport for this country. The results also include the fact that the Auditor-General has drawn attention to something to which I have attempted to draw attention over the years. I am delighted that the Auditor-General has now supported what I have said; that is, that it is quite wrong to capitalise interest and pretend that one cannot disclose that interest payment as an operating cost and, therefore, improve one' s results.

According to the Auditor-General, what has happened as far as TAA is concerned, is that subject to the period about which I am talking being to 30 June 1982 TAA after about 36 years of operation had a market capitalisation of just under $30m . If its accounts were restructured, as the Auditor-General says they ought to be, that market capitalisation would be reduced by $23m, leaving TAA, our major public enterprise in the air transport sector other than Qantas Airways Ltd-that is, our major domestic airline-with a market capitalisation of about $7m net after 36 years of existence. That must be a cause for alarm to a lot of people who would like to see public sector enterprises successful in this country. It must be a cause of some satisfaction to those who would like to see public sector enterprises shown to be unsuccessful in this country.

The point I make in briefly speaking to the report is that I believe what is going on is a cause for considerable concern and for some debate in this chamber . I started making the point, in fairness, that TAA cannot be taken on a strict comparison basis with its competitor but it is a matter which ought not to be ignored by the chamber in considering the report. I therefore seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CAIRNS SECTION ZONING PLAN AND THE CORMORANT PASS SECTION ZONING PLAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper and the statement.

The Cormorant Pass and Cairns sections of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park were proclaimed on 21 October 1981 and 19 November 1981 respectively. These sections cover an area of approximately 36,000 square kilometres. This is a very important step forward in the declaration of the entire Barrier Reef as a marine park, a step which is welcomed, particularly by Queenslanders and also by Australians generally.

The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority advertised in December 1981, following the proclamations of these two areas, its intention to prepare zoning plans for the Cairns and Cormorant Pass sections and called for public representations in connection with the proposed plans. Some 200 representations were received and the Authority, I believe, indicated that those representations , particularly on the subject of how the public uses the various reefs in the sections, were of a very high quality. Two-thirds of the representations came from areas adjacent to the Cairns section, indicating a high level of local involvement in planning the marine area. The Authority took these public representations into consideration and developed zoning plans for the Cairns and Cormorant Pass sections. The draft zoning plans were released for public review on 7 September 1982 and Authority staff were subsequently engaged in an active public participation program. The receipt of representations closed at the end of 1982. After this program closed, the plans were revised by the Marine Park Authority and are the ones tabled in the Senate today.

I mention all those events and dates to point out the level and extent of consultation that has gone into every area of the zoning of different parts of the Marine Park. The Authority indicated that it has received throughout assistance from the Queensland Government agencies in the development of the zoning plans. In 1982 the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council requested the Marine Park Authority, in consultation with Queensland Government officers, to recommend a timetable for declaration of future sections of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. In the 1982-83 Budget and subsequently in the Parliament the Fraser Government announced its intention to accelerate the declaration of sections of the Marine Park. The Ministerial Council has agreed that the declaration of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park also should be accelerated. The major areas of the Great Barrier Reef region not already in the Marine Park are the Whitsunday area, the Townsville area and the far north area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to questions that were asked yesterday by the Opposition about the alleged size of the deficit for 1983-84. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, there is no revised forecast. The Treasury is currently preparing a revised forecast. I will ask the Treasurer to make that available when it is complete, noting as I do so that the practice under the previous Government was not to release any Treasury forecasts whatsoever. Apparently the attitude of the Liberal Party to that policy matter has changed since it moved into Opposition. I can advise the Senate of some facts, as distinct from what the discredited former Treasurer has been saying about this matter, relevant to both the 6 March Treasury estimate and the National Economic Summit Conference scenario A. There was no gross domestic product growth assumption per se in the 6 March estimate. There was a forecast that total employment would fall by one per cent on average during the year, which led some people to conclude that there was an implicit forecast of GDP growth of 0.5 per cent, the reason for the discrepancy being an assumed productivity growth of 1.5 per cent. In fact Mr Stone has since stated, the Treasurer has stated this in the House, that the GDP assumption underlying the 6 March paper was 1.5 per cent real GDP growth on average-in other words, an implicit productivity gain of 2.5 per cent. Some people may think this is high but in times of labour shedding at the margin one would expect the productivity growth rate to be somewhat higher than normal.

ANSWER.PARA: Last week the discredited former Treasurer said that the forecast real GDP growth rate had increased from 0.5 per cent to 4.1 per cent. He was wrong at both ends, because the growth rate assumed in the 6 March statement was 1.5 per cent and the latest estimate which came from a revision of scenario A is for a year-on-year growth of 3.1 per cent. So the appropriate figures to use in the context in which the discredited former Treasurer used figures last week would be a revision from 1.5 per cent on 6 March to 3.1 per cent-not 0.5 per cent to 4 .1 per cent, as he stated. It appears that, unlike Senator Messner, the discredited former Treasurer cannot understand the difference between a June-on- June growth rate and a year-on-year growth rate. As anyone who knows the slightest thing about these matters-Senator Messner is one of the few people in the Liberal Party who do-would know for the purposes of assessing effect on Commonwealth revenue the year-on-year figure is relevant. It is no surprise, perhaps, that the former Treasurer does not understand the significance for Commonwealth revenue purposes of a year-on-year or June-on-June figure, given the dreadful mess in which he left the Country Party-the country's finances.
Honourable senators interjecting-

ANSWER.PARA: Over and above the errors which the discredited former Treasurer has committed in making the assertions that he did, there is another very important matter of government revenue in relation to next year. A good deal of the anticipated additional growth arises from the agricultural sector because the drought has broken. The revenue gains from that will not be received in 1983-84, but in 1984 -85. I see that Senator Messner is nodding his head. That means he understands that little complexity too. It is a pity Mr Howard did not share his insight into these matters. A good deal of the potential revenue, even from the non-farm sector, gained from a higher growth rate will be deferred into the next financial year.

I commend to the discredited former Treasurer a perusal of an article written by his former adviser, Mr John Hewson, and published in the Business Review Weekly last week, which deals with some of those matters. With respect to scenario A the assumed year-on-year gross domestic product growth rate was 2.7 per cent. I understand that Dr Hughes and Dr Garnaut, at the briefing provided for the Press on 19 May, said that they believed that growth rate has now increased to something slightly above 3 per cent-3.1 per cent at the highest. So the difference between scenario A and what Drs Hughes and Garnaut said at the 19 May briefing is at most a 0.4 per cent greater increase in GDP in a normal year. A broadly based GDP of that magnitude will increase government revenue by about $200m. Given that a great deal of that increase is not broadly based but originates from the agricultural sector and stockholdings, the actual gain to revenue will be considerably less than that. So although there has been some change because of new facts which have arisen, since both scenario A and the 6 March statement, it is a reasonable expectation that the $9.6 billion deficit forecast by Treasury for next financial year-other things being equal-will now be somewhat less than that. Essentially, however, it makes absolutely no difference to this point: The former Treasurer was told four days before the election that the deficit would be between $9 billion and $10 billion; on the day before the election he was told it would be $9.6 billion.

—Has the Attorney-General seen the recent comment in the Age newspaper by Professor Finlay of Monash University that the legal and ethical questions raised by in vitro fertilisation could be resolved more quickly if, instead of the five separate State inquiries now being conducted, the Federal Government established a national committee? What is the Commonwealth's role in this matter? What are the implications of in vitro fertilisation for laws governing the status of children, including inheritance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen Professor Finlay's article in the Melbourne Age . The situation is as follows: Inquiries into in vitro fertilisation are presently being undertaken in three Australian States-New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland-and also outside Australia, to our knowledge, in Ontario and Great Britain. The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General would appear to be the most effective available body for the consideration and co-ordination of the State reports and I propose to ensure that the matter continues to be raised before that forum. To the extent that the Standing Committee so operates it would appear to be unnecessary for the Commonwealth to set up an additional inquiry of its own, but that is certainly a question that I will keep under review if other forms of co-ordinating activity break down.

ANSWER.PARA: At present the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General is considering this matter to the extent that it is looking at a draft model Bill produced by New South Wales which deals with artificial insemination by donor and in vitro fertilisation where donor material is used. This Bill deals only with the determination of the relationship of father and child, although it recognises the possibility of ovum donation and surrogate motherhood. It does not deal with the issue of who is the mother in such a situation. In the AID and IVF situations with which this model Bill deals, it is proposed that the status situation be resolved by severing the legal link with the donor. Insofar as IVF involves no donor genetic material, no issues as to the status of the resulting child are raised, because in law such a child is of no different status from a child naturally conceived. However, there is a question in relation to children born as a result of medical techniques using donor genetic material, who have not had their status dealt with adequately. As I have said, the draft model legislation is directed to this area.

As to the effect on inheritance laws, inevitably there would be some effect of the kind of legislation that I have talked about as it would result in some children being more completely regarded as children of the families into which they have been born. The draft model Bill will overcome difficulties which are presently being experienced in that area.

As I have said, the Commonwealth's role at the moment is, I perceive, a relatively limited one, that is, assisting in the co-ordination of this reporting activity that is now going on and certainly legislating for the Australian Capital Territory when the time arrives to do so. Let me mention one remaining aspect of the Commonwealth's role, and that concerns the Family Law Amendment Bill which will be introduced later today. The Bill contains a provision allowing an AID or IVF child to be treated in all respects as a child of the marriage for the purpose in that respect--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is exactly the same as the previous Bill, is it?

—Yes. Senator Durack will be delighted to find that his product lingers on in that respect even if his memory in other ways is becoming rapidly diminished. To that extent-and it is only to that extent-the Family Law Act will deal with this vexed and controversial question. The Family Law Amendment Bill provision which is proposed in this respect is not in any way designed to deal with these basic questions of status which do remain to be resolved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

The rural community has not been singled out to carry a disproportionate share of the fiscal restraint which was outlined in the May statement. Indeed, rural communities will share perhaps even more than other Australians in the benefits which will ultimately be derived from the May statement in the form of moderation of interest rates and cost increases. These things have been of greatest concern to the rural community over a number of years. I point out that a number of the measures which were introduced in the May statement will have a direct impact on primary producers. The major impact will come through the contribution of all the individual measures working together to restore balance and growth to an economy- particularly a rural economy-which has suffered severe difficulties in recent times.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of specific benefits for rural communities are contained in the May statement. I could give a number of other examples; to single out one, it is a fact that primary producers, unlike other taxpayers, will still be able to claim a full year's depreciation in the year in which plant is purchased. The major impact of the May statement on rural communities will come ultimately with the restoration of balance and growth to the Australian economy. They are the things which the rural community and rural organisations have been complaining about for many years. A strengthening of the domestic economy in Australia is of advantage to every rural producer.

I must say that both before the May economic statement and since the Government has had quite detailed discussions with representatives of farm and rural organisations, who do not make the claims which have been made by people such as Mr Anthony, that the rural sector has been singled out in a disadvantageous way from other sectors of the community; there is widespread recognition that all sectors of the community had to share in the constraints which arose from the May economic statement. That is recognised by rural organisations and this recognition has been conveyed to members of the Government in discussions which have been held since the statement was made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether the Government is aware of statements in the 23 May issue of Newsweek magazine in an article on Aboriginal land rights, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: In many parts of rural Australia 'shoot-em-up' is a favourite weekend sport. The rules are simple. Drunken whites ride through country towns firing random gunshots in Aboriginal neighbourhoods. The Aborigines may be killed . . . but few whites go to gaol.

In view of the large international circulation of Newsweek and its general reputation for accuracy, I ask that an investigation of these allegations be carried out. I ask the Minister to establish whether the allegations have any basis in fact. If they have, will she see that appropriate action is taken? If they have not, will she find out why they were made and do all she can to see that Newsweek corrects the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the article in Newsweek to which Senator Mason's question referred. Whilst I would say, and I express here the view of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Clyde Holding, that the stories were alarmist, there is no doubt that some aspects of the stories reflect the extraordinary circumstances of discrimination under which Aboriginal Australians live and the violence to which they are subjected from time to time. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Clyde Holding, has informed me that the particular allegation concerning weekend parties going out to shoot Aboriginals is untrue. I do not know what investigations he has undertaken to ascertain that, and I will refer that aspect of Senator Mason's question to him.

ANSWER.PARA: All honourable senators will be aware that violence of this kind is something from which Aboriginal Australians are not free. Honourable senators will be aware of the tragic episode in Moree last year, although it was an isolated incident as the publicity it attracted demonstrated. The Government certainly would not claim that there is a complete absence of racial discrimination in rural Australia. On the other hand, we believe it is going beyond fair and accurate reporting to suggest that the occurrences described in Newsweek are a normal part of life in Australia.

The Government's intention is to take as many effective steps as possible to eliminate discrimination, both through strengthening the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act, which was a Whitlam Government initiative, and through co- operation and consultation with Aboriginal people throughout Australia to ensure that the social and economic circumstances of Aboriginal people are improved so that the basis for the kind of prejudiced behaviour that gives rise to these outbursts of violence can be eliminated. I will refer Senator Mason's question, specifically that part with regard to investigation of the allegations in the Newsweek article, to Mr Holding. I will also carry to him the suggestion implied in Senator Mason's question that any false allegations in Newsweek ought to be corrected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Finance advise the Senate of the effect on the personal income tax obligations of ordinary wage and salary earners of the loss of $200m in government revenue from other sources in 1983-84?

—If the Government lost a couple of hundred million in revenue and had to recover it from some other source, not only in 1983-84 but also, I suppose, in any year, the magnitude of the changes that would have to be made- these are single alternatives that I am putting and not a group-would involve an average rise in income tax of nearly $1 a week. Of course, for many households with more than one income earner it would be more than $1. Alternatively, there could be a 7 per cent increase in sales tax collections, which would add about 0 .25 per cent to the consumer price index. If the adjustment were to be made on the expenditure side, for example, $200m represents approximately 30 per cent of the amount of total Commonwealth payments to Tasmania. I am not sure of the proportion it represents of payments to other States. That is an indication of the sorts of alternatives which would be available to a government if that revenue were lost for whatever reason. I suppose that I should add one other alternative; that is, it could be added to whatever Budget deficit would otherwise apply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to his Press statement of 24 May relating to changes to the Freedom of Information Act, and remind him of his and the Government's firm election commitment which stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Labor will implement fully the outstanding recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs to ensure that freedom of information operates in practice as well as in name.

I ask the Attorney-General: First, does not his statement of 24 May omit the major recommendations of the Senate Committee relating to conclusive certificates and to the increased use of the Commonwealth Ombudsman? Secondly, will the Government honour its pre-election and subsequent undertakings to eliminate the iniquitous system of conclusive certificates which allows Ministers to arrogate to themselves unappealable powers to prevent the release of certain classes of documents? Thirdly, will major amendments be made to the Act, as recommended by the Senate Committee, to provide for an effective involvement of the Ombudsman in the practical utilisation of freedom of information?

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Missen reads the Bill to be introduced tomorrow, of which I gave notice today, he will, I think, be not quite so disappointed as he sounds at the moment about the reach and scope of that Bill, which contains some references and makes some substantial improvements to the present system which obtains in relation to conclusive certificates and gives certain clarification and minor extension to the role of the Ombudsman. I have readily acknowledged publicly that sometimes there is a gap between aspiration and achievement when it comes to the implementation--
—What about your promises, too? There seems to be a gap between that and your promises.
—There was neither aspiration nor achievement in Senator Durack's case. I think he has very little to be proud of in his record.
—Order! I suggest that the Attorney-General answer Senator Missen' s question.

—I think the question would be better directed to me during the debate on the Bill, which Bill is a substantial one and makes a great many improvements to the scope and operation of the Freedom of Information Act, based overwhelmingly on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, of which Senator Missen and I were both members. The Government and I share the honourable senator's commitment to effective freedom of information legislation. I am sure that the legislation will be very substantially improved by the character of the amendments which are coming forward.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am aware of what is in the statement of the Attorney and that the Bill will not contain these items. Cannot the Attorney admit that the Government is not now going to carry out its election undertaking to implement the Senate Committee's recommendations ?

—I repeat that the Bill coming forward will not quite meet that aspiration in every respect, two significant respects being conclusive certificates and the role of the Ombudsman. There is no secret about that, because I identified those two particular matters in the Press statement to which the honourable senator referred. There is no attempt to duck or weave on this issue. It is simply a matter of saying that there are many things one would like to do that, for one reason or another, do not always prove possible to achieve all at once.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that the supporting parent's benefit can be paid by the Department of Social Security to a mother who lives abroad with her child? Is it a fact that a number of women, including but not confined to New Zealanders, abuse this provision by giving birth to their child in Australia and then returning to New Zealand or to their home country, where the Australian taxpayer continues financial support for many years? Will the Government consider taking firm steps to halt this practice, which not only drains away much needed dollars from our own social security system but, I believe, also badly sours some aspects of our relations with the home countries of these women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate is correct in saying that the supporting parent's benefit is, in fact, portable to any country in the world. As he has mentioned in particular New Zealand, which has been the subject of questions in this place at other times, I think it is important to point out that the benefit is payable in New Zealand, and that rumours periodically go round the community that apparently a large number of New Zealand women are abusing this facility. To put the matter into perspective, I should point out that about 2.6 million pensions and benefits are paid by this country each year. Of that total, only 17,000 are paid as portable pensions overseas and only 157 supporting parent's benefits are paid to women who are living in New Zealand. As frequently an associated rumour is that about pensions paid to women in Fiji, I say that only 161 such pensions are paid in the whole of Oceania. At various times attacks are made on the portability provisions of the social security legislation which, as most honourable senators know, were introduced in 1973 and were continued throughout the life of the previous Government. This Government agrees with the provision of portability.
—What about contrived cases?

—I have answered the question by pointing out that one could hardly describe the payment of 157 supporting parent's benefits to people living in New Zealand as representing an enormous drain on the Australian taxpayer and an abuse of the Australian Treasury. I put it to honourable senators that the stories that go round about New Zealand women are just not borne out by the facts. That has been pointed out by not only me but also previous Ministers for Social Security.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I am aware that New Zealand does not provide such portability for this group of people. Australia will be renegotiating the reciprocal agreement on social security between Australia and New Zealand and that is a matter that we will have to discuss. There will always be people who will try to take advantage of the social security provisions. I merely wish to point out that if, amongst those 157 to whom the supporting parent's benefit is paid, there are some who are abusing those provisions, the way to overcome that is to review the situation carefully, in the light particularly of negotiations with the New Zealand Government, to ensure that people on either side of the Tasman do not abuse the social security system of either country. Therefore, we will continue to take a close look at the matter, which I will be discussing with my New Zealand counterpart when the time comes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. On Tuesday of last week, in answer to a question asked by Senator Messner, the Minister said that contracts for the supply of uranium had been refused by the former Government because of 'unsatisfactory pricing arrangements '. I ask: Is it a fact that the former Government did not approve a contract that had been entered into by the Pancontinental company because the technical details relating to price review procedures were unsatisfactory? Would the Minister agree that this is a totally separate issue from that of contract prices for an agreed quantity of uranium?

—No, I do not agree. I repeat what I said in the Senate on, I believe, the day mentioned, and what I have said on a number of occasions outside of the Senate. The plain fact is that the former Minister for Trade and Resources, Mr Anthony, declined to approve a provisional contract which had been drawn up, because the pricing arrangements were not satisfactory. That is what happened and that is what I said.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, refers to the introduction of computers in schools and the training of teachers in computer instruction. Will the Minister advise what steps are being taken to ensure appropriate computer literacy of teachers? Will the Minister give consideration to encouraging informal participation of parents to overcome the educational gap between students and parents that will exist when school computer studies are fully implemented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has announced, and indeed has started to implement, its policy of developing a computer education program for all government secondary schools in Australia and all needy non-government schools. Computer programs already exist in many non-government and some government schools. However, we are very well aware that in implementing a new program of this kind we have to look beyond the actual introduction of the hardware, the computer itself. We must look further than the development of curricula materials and consider very seriously teacher development so that courses will be properly taught and integrated with existing educational courses. We have also to consider community participation to ensure close understanding and support on the part of the school community, particularly the parents, in an innovation of this kind.

ANSWER.PARA: We are all too aware from past experiences that if innovations of this kind are introduced without the proper teacher preparation and without community and parent appreciation of the purpose of the innovation, the innovation can fail. We are determined that this innovation will not fail because it is very pertinent in terms of the needs of the economy, the future shape of the work force and the role that computers already play in our economy. Because we are determined that we will succeed, we are taking very careful steps in the planning to do what was implied in Senator Elstob's question, and that is to involve teachers and parents in the community and industry representatives in the entire development of this program. A national computer education inquiry is being conducted by the Schools Commission covering all of these matters. I will make available to Senator Elstob all of the details of the committees and the sub-committees so that he can rest assured that the matters touched on in his question have been taken note of by the Government and are being dealt with very carefully.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer him to his earlier answer to Senator Macklin's question and I ask: Is it a fact that the Australian Labor Party's minimum position in regard to uranium mining is to phase out existing mines and that certain conditions must be applied if existing mines are allowed to continue in operation? What conditions have been imposed on Energy Resources of Australia and Queensland Mines Ltd in regard to their negotiations for new contracts?

—I have answered those questions before. I said that the specific means of implementing the Australian Labor Party's policy are under review and that I will seek from Mr Bowen who handles these matters the details of what is being done in respect of the producers.
—I asked what conditions have been imposed.
—I have already said that I cannot answer that here. I will refer that matter to Mr Bowen for an answer.

—I claim your indulgence, Mr President, to clarify or correct an answer I gave to Senator Townley in which I believe I said that no decision had been made on whether the widow, for example-I am not sure whether it is ever applicable to a spouse as potentially distinct from a widow-of a deceased superannuitant who is entitled to the lump sum which would otherwise have been payable to the deceased would be taxed on it. I believe I said that no decision had been made on that matter and that I would clarify it with the Treasurer. I have now been advised by the Treasurer that in those circumstances a widow or spouse, if applicable, who receives a lump sum which was the entitlement of a deceased person would be taxed in the same way as though the lump sum had been received by the deceased person. I am also advised that that was stated on page 61 of attachment B to the 19 May statement. I left for Perth early that day and did not, in fact, receive attachment B on that day. I have not read it since. I attribute my lack of knowledge of the Treasurer having made that statement only to that fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) for his correction. So that the record is clear, Senator Townley's question also related to a statement made by Mr Keating yesterday to that effect. I merely wish to confirm that a statement to that effect was made yesterday on AM by Mr Keating.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 1.4 to 2.15 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-At Question Time today, in a question to Senator Walsh, Senator Archer referred to an answer I gave on the projected Budget deficit to several questions by way of interjections from Senators Messner and MacGibbon during my speech last night in the debate on the May economic statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). It may be recalled that in my speech last night I said that after the election the Government had discovered that the Budget deficit was in fact in the order of $9.6 billion. Prior to the election the then Treasurer had led the community of Australia to believe that the Budget deficit would be more like $6 billion. Last night the questions, by way of persistent interjection, were:

SPEECH.PARA: Which year are we talking about? . . . For which year?
And later--
Which financial year? . . . Which year?
And--
Which year?

My answer to the second interjection prompted today's question from Senator Archer. I answered: For the currrent year. Of course I should have said that it was for the end of the 1983-84 financial year, based on projecting the effects of the 1982-83 Budget to that time. If I have misled anyone I apologise but I would have thought that the fact that I made an error of timing would have been clear to Opposition senators because at the relevant passage in my speech I compared the prediction of the Department of the Treasury of $9.6 billion with Mr Howard's prediction of $6 billion for the same period. The fact I strived to point out was that the Treasury had projected a $9.6 billion deficit but Mr Howard had said $6 billion-a fact, since the only question is to year, which I am glad to see is not disputed by the Opposition. I am pleased that Senator Archer asked his question today. I intended to correct the situation when I spoke next but his question has enabled me to make this explanation earlier.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President has received a letter from Senator Peter Rae proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Minister for Industry and Commerce to take any appropriate steps to overcome those problems of industry which are causing loss of both jobs and investment.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate and I also thank Senator Walsh for so speedily responding to the request made by the Opposition that some steps be taken to educate some members of the Government in relation to economic realities. We have just heard, by way of personal explanation, the first result from that process; but that is not what we are debating today. What we are debating today is a matter which can perhaps be best summed up by a simple question. Where is the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button)? He is known as the Minister for I Don't Know.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Button laughs, very appropriately, because that is about what he does in relation to all of the problems which are besetting this country now, as I will demonstrate in a moment. But let me first sum up the Minister's attitude in this way:

SPEECH.PARA: Hey diddle diddle,
The cat and the fiddle,
The cow jumped over the moon;
The little dog laughed,
To see such sport,
And the dish ran away with the spoon.

Inflation and unemployment are the dish and the spoon, while Senator Button laughs. That is the problem that we have in this country. The Australian in its editorial on 19 May referred to 'the Government's vague economic aims'. It also stated:
The Federal Government has baulked at making any real decisions in the economic area and it is time action matched its rhetoric.

Let me just quote this well-informed Minister's contribution to the debate which has been taking place in relation to his areas of responsibility. These are matters which may or may not assist in getting Australia back to work, which is his responsibility. On 25 May, in relation to taxation on superannuation payments, he said in answer to a question:
I an unaware of any undertakings given by the Prime Minister. When I say I am unaware, I am not denying that undertakings were given; I just do not know.
Again, in answer to a question on the same subject that day, he said:
. . . I will obtain an answer for the honourable senator in due course on the other aspects of the question.
No Minister is necessarily conversant with all the facts, but I will find them out.

This is a Cabinet Minister speaking. On the same day in relation to income tax concessions on health insurance-on this matter apparently the Minister was part of the decision-making process in terms of what this Government is doing to manage the economy of Australia-he said:
I am not aware that the pre-election statement was made in that context.
He went on to say something further about the housing interest subsidy. In answer to another question, he said:
I do not personally recall that pre-election commitment.
A little later, in relation to taxation on superannuation payments, he was asked the question:
Can the Leader of the Government now tell me, as he was unable to do yesterday, whether the Prime Minister gave a post-election undertaking not to alter taxation of lump sum superannuation payments?
The Minister-the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister responsible for getting Australia going again-said:
The answer to the first part of the question, I am sorry, is no.

He was then asked a further question by his own colleague and my namesake from the other side of the Senate, Senator Robert Ray, on Telecom Australia and starting price betting. The Minister's answer was:
I am unaware of any information having been forwarded to the Minister for Communications . . .
We hear around the traps the joke that the Minister for Industry and Commerce, whilst neglecting anything to do with industry and commerce, is known as the shadowy Minister for Communications.
Further, on 26 May, in relation to income tax rebates on health insurance, he was able to answer Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle by saying:
I have not yet obtained that information . . .
Which was sought. On the same day, he was asked the following question by Senator Watson:

Has the memory of the Leader of the Government in the Senate been refreshed to the extent that he can now recall the Government's election commitment to continue the existing tax concession on mortgage interest payments?
Senator Button replied:
No, not yet. I will try next week.

Smart-Alick. The little dog laughed, as we have the problem of the dish running away with the spoon. This is the problem which besets Australia while the Minister laughs as he did when I commenced my remarks today. No doubt he will try to laugh off the real questions which I propose to raise.

Let us just have a look at some of the real questions. How was the question of the steel industry dealt with in the economic statement-the much vaunted economic statement? The Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, is one of the leading people involved presumably in its preparation. What did that statement do for industry? I have been through the statement and I have summarised it in this way: The statement referred to transport. It proposed an increase in the price of fuel which will result in higher freight charges. It also proposed an increase in the excise duty on Avgas . These two increases will add next year $25m to the cost of industry which is the area for which his Department is responsible. The decisions announced in the statement are inflationary; they are certainly anti-small business. The Government proposes to cut back on airport development. Decisions taken in the statement will effectively cut out construction of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway and a lot of work in respect of Whyalla about which my colleague Senator Jessop will talk in detail. There again, there was nothing for manufacturing, was there, Mr Minister for Industry and Commerce?

What did the Government do in respect of communications? Communications is apparently beloved of our Minister for baiting Dame Leonie Kramer. We have all heard about Button versus Kramer but what have we heard about the communications industry? The economic statement says that the Government will sell 49 per cent of Aussat Pty Ltd if it does not scrap it altogether. It will increase, by $100m , Telecom Australia's contribution to the Government revenues which again could be regarded only as either inflationary and proof that the Government regards it as a milking cow or just inflationary. But it certainly does nothing to assist encouraging manufacturing industry for Telecom expansion.

The next heading in the economic statement is 'Other Industry Measures'. What do we find? Firstly we find that the Government has decided to terminate depreciation for fuel storage and fuel conversions. This is another hit at the rural sector and another hit at manufacturing industry. What, did that do in the Minister's area of responsibility? I presume that as a senior Cabinet Minister the honourable senator takes some responsibility for the economic statement. The second point raised was tax take aways for primary producers. Several measures were put forward, but there was certainly nothing for manufacturing industry which relies upon primary producers to buy a lot of its products. The third point that was raised was canning the Bicentennial Water Resources Program. I do not know what that did for manufacturers of machinery and other people who were involved in the manufacturing sector, for which the Minister is responsible. It certainly did not help their sales or their prospects. It did nothing, as the housing proposals did nothing, to encourage anyone to believe that there was anything other than a lessened or diminished prospect of economic activity. Housing proposals were deferred effectively by transfer and diminishment between 1 July and 1 October. Unless the present Western Australian Labor Government's proposal-supported as I understand it by honourable senators on the opposite side of the chamber, who are a bit more far-sighted than this Government-is accepted by the Government something will have to be done to keep the housing industry on its upturn during that period, otherwise there will be a massive downturn and again nothing for manufacturing industry. It is extraordinary that this Minister-a Minister in a senior position responsible for getting Australia and industry and commerce going again-has participated in what amounts to a series of decisions outlined in the economic statement of 19 May which hit below the belt the very people who elected the Government. We are told that the mortgage belt rebelled. The mortgage belt has now been hit below the belt by this Government and this Minister.

I will refer to some other aspects of this Minister's behaviour in relation to industry advisory councils. During the period leading up to the election we were told by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, that we were to be overcome with a wonderful spirit of consensus. We were to have commitments to use the talents of both parties. On 16 February, Mr Hawke said:
The need for national reconciliation, the need for Australians to be brought together and to work together, is something I held as fundamental throughout my public career.
Yet what has the Minister done to pursue that ideal? He has suspended the operation of the industry advisory councils, as far as the Opposition is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Government.
—And Government members. If I may just develop it a little further--
—The allegation is just not true. You should get your facts right .
—I will quote from the Minister's letter to me--
—You named the industry advisory councils. That is one.
—Yes. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . regarding Opposition representation on both the Australian Manufacturing Council and the nine Industry Advisory Councils,-
This is a letter from the Minister for I Don't Know, the Minister who is again proving that he does not know what he has actually written-

I wish to advise that as the longer term arrangements for Councils are under review, attendance of parliamentary delegates, both Government and Opposition, has been suspended for the time being. As soon as the longer term issues relating to Councils have been resolved, I shall contact you again regarding this matter.

That is a letter to me from the Minister dated 11 May 1983. Only one day prior to that letter being received by me the Estimates committees were told by a senior public servant that the Opposition would be represented on these councils and the Minister did nothing to refute what was said, although he was present during that discussion. The senior public servant said, as reported on page 7 of the Senate Estimates Committee Hansard of 10 May:
Membership of the Steel Industry Advisory Council . . .
I indicate that this was mentioned together with other groups-
is . . . and two parliamentary representatives, one from the Government and one from the Opposition.

As time is short, let me just refer to some further aspects of this Minister's co-operation and consensus. We have Mr Justice Fisher's report on the New South Wales steel industry-a matter of great importance to Australia and a matter which is causing great concern to a large number of people in Australia. Are we to have a steel industry and is there to be further huge unemployment and disinvestment? What do we find? We find that, although this report was presented on 23 May, I, as the Opposition spokesman, have still not been able to obtain a copy of it, either from the Federal Labor Government or the State Labor Government. I was told as recently as this morning by the staff in the office of the Minister for I Don't Know that they could not let me have a copy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is that? That is me, I suppose?

—That is Senator Button. The Industries Assistance Commission' s final report on the steel industry went to the Government last Thursday-a matter of some considerable importance. It has already been written up in all the media. It has been leaked to the media but the Opposition cannot obtain access to it from this consensus Government. Again, as recently as this morning, I was refused a copy of that report by the Minister's office. I was told that it is confidential until it has been considered by Cabinet. But the Press has it. This consensus Government, which is proposing to use the term 'bringing Australia together' as a new form of government, refuses to let a copy of that important report be made available to the Opposition even on a confidential basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party committed itself to preserving the steel industry virtually at all cost and before receiving professional advice. A commitment was made during the election campaign to this effect:
The Labor Government gives an unequivocal commitment to the maintenance of a viable and efficient steel industry in this country.

I inform Senator Button that his leader, Mr Hawke, said that in the Australian Labor Party's policy speech of 16 February. He also made the statement, from which the Government has since resiled, that the decisions would be taken within 100 days of the Labor Government assuming office. I accept and congratulate the Government on resiling from that commitment. It was a commitment that should not have been made; it was irresponsible at the time it was made. The one responsible action for which I commend the Government is for saying that it would endeavour logically to reach a conclusion in relation to the steel industry. I just regret that the Minister does not find the idea of consensus worth while. Just a couple of days after the receipt by the Government of the IAC's final report Mr Hawke described the report as being highly contentious. He said:
The Government will not be bound by its recommendations but will treat the report simply as one source of advice to be considered along with other advice.

I presume that the Minister was present when the Prime Minister made that statement on Monday this week. I just wonder what other independent sources of advice the Government sought and what advice it intends to seek in relation to this matter. Will it be what Mr Hawke referred to, again on Monday, when he said :
. . . a tripartite committee of government, the company and unions was investigating how retrenchments could be avoided in future 'and a voluntary retirement scheme put in place as an alternative'.

Again there was no consultation with the Opposition. We have come to accept this as par for the course with this Minister. There was no consultation with anybody else either, other than those who were involved and have become part of this Government's modus operandi-big government, big business and big unions. That was what the National Economic Summit Conference was all about, that is what this Government is all about, and that was what was reaffirmed in relation to Australia's major problem at the moment in regard to the industry and commerce area, that is, the steel industry. On Monday of this week the Prime Minister reaffirmed that that is the approach of this Government. I wonder what is the position when I hear answers such as that given by the Minister for Industry and Commerce in relation to the manufacturing industry, which is a principal responsibility of his. On 24 May I asked him whether he agreed with the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, who said:

Australia's declining employment in manufacturing is permanent, irreversible and structural. In my view it is not temporary or to be rectified by tariffs, wage freezes, bounties, quotas or other fiscal measures.

The Minister for Industry and Commerce basically agreed with that statement. He said that he agreed with the second part of the question, that the problem was not to be rectified by tariffs, wage freezes, bounties, quotas or other fiscal measures. In relation to the first part of the question he said:

A number of people . . . suggest that by the turn of the century manufacturing employment in Australia, as we traditionally know it, will probably decline to about 12 per cent of total employment. I am unable to say whether that view is correct.

He is not only the Minister for I Don't Know but also the Minister for No Hope. That is the concern of the Opposition, that no hope is being held out in any way . As I have identified from the answers to questions, we have not only the Minister for I Don't Know but also the Minister for No Hope. The bane of contention by the Opposition is that in relation to all of these important questions on protection the Minister says: 'I don't know'. If the Minister has regard to his answers to the Estimates Committee, he will find-I have not time to cite them all-that his answers were either 'I don't know' or 'It is being looked at'. Dumping is being looked at. With regard to employment, his answer was: 'I don't know'. . . . it is still not possible to discern the general economic principles which Mr Hawke and his colleagues intend to follow now that they hold office.

For another, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, has indicated that there was little the Federal Government 'could or would do' to help the ailing car manufacturer.

Hey diddle diddle,
The cat and the fiddle
The cow jumped over the moon;
The little dog laughed--

As a general comment, I thought the only area of the speech from the shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Peter Rae, in which he spoke with any passion was in his personal invective against me. If he wants to do that, he should at least get his wires untangled about the topic to which he was supposed to be addressing himself, expressed in the words of his own matter of public importance. He had a lot of passion in terms of personal invective.

In the whole time that we have been in government he has asked two questions about industry and commerce matters and in the course of the debate today he has chosen to misrepresent both of my answers to those questions. He knows he has misrepresented them, particularly the answer I gave in relation to employment. If Senator Rae wants me to tell lies, as the Fraser Government did, about projections of employment in manufacturing industry, I will not oblige him. If we are to indulge in literary quotation, his speech was-I do not want to reveal the first line; Senator Rae can look it up-a speech 'full of sound and fury, signifying nothing'. If Senator Peter Rae wants that indulgence from me, I am sorry, he will not get it. But if he wants indulgence regarding the Fisher report and if he directs an honest question or a letter to me, I will reply and he will get a copy of the Fisher report. He never had the decency to do that. He came in here today and said that he spoke to a member of my staff about the Fisher report but could not get it. TALK.START.PARA: —Why should I not contact your staff when I cannot get appointments with you to discuss things like the PVC case, because you know all about it and you don't want to talk about it.
—To my knowledge the honourable senator has not sought an appointment with me about that matter.
—I have.

—Well, the honourable senator can go on rumbling away. I have told him that I will give him a copy of the Fisher report if he asks me for it, instead of using it as a little matchstick to try to beat me with in the Senate. I want to talk about some of the problems which industry does face, which were not addressed in any way by Senator Rae. It is hard to overestimate the extent of those problems. Not only did we inherit 10 weeks ago an economy in absolutely appalling shape, but also we inherited years of neglect in relation to industry policy. As an example I point to the May 1983 edition of the 'Investment Overview' of Potter Partners, share brokers. That firm is not a particular friend of ours, but this is what it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government inherited an economy arguably in the worst shape for 50 years: negative Gross Domestic Product growth; inflation and unemployment both in double digit figures; severe drought; and a projected 1983/84 Budget deficit in the order of 6 per cent of GDP.

That is what that firm had to say about the economy which we inherited. But let us look at what Opposition spokesmen and former Ministers have had to say about industry policy over the last four or five years. I will not refer to them in the plural, I will just select one-the great Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), who attracts something like 27 per cent of popular support in the Australian community. In an address to industry on industry policy on 7 December 1982, in his brief sojourn as Minister for Industry and Commerce, and talking about that year, he said:

Conditions over the past year, fuelled by excessive wage gains, have resulted in a loss of competitiveness in industry, a squeeze on profits and a consequent rapid decline in employment opportunities.
In October, a little earlier in the year, Mr Peacock said:
But while international pressures were accumulating, we have . . . by generating some problems of our own making-in particular the excessive wage increases which have occurred over the last year.

That was the rhetoric of the Government from which we took over-everything wrong with Australian industry was due to wages. No other questions were addressed. When the Opposition wanted to find a scapegoat for industry's ills, which have accumulated over 25 years under conservative governments, it blamed wages. It is still doing it this year as an opposition in the Senate-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the 25 per cent across the board tariff cut occurred under a Labor government.

—The honourable senator can go back to that if he wants, but he did not mention it. He has not mentioned it for ages. It is something he has plucked out of the top of his head, like his speech. For years wages have been blamed as the cause of all Australia's industry problems. Of course, they make a contribution and the Government recognises that. This Government has a wages policy. Many of the difficulties, but by no means all, with which industry is now faced, occurred because of the absence of a wages policy at the time of conservative government. Difficulties are still coming through the system in 1983 as a result of the abandonment of a wages policy in 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: We inherited not only those sorts of economic difficulties, but also an industry structure staggering under the weight of years of unprincipled, ad hoc decision-making, lack of planning by conservative governments and a lot of high- minded rhetoric and policy on the run in relation to industry. To prove that point it is not necessary only to listen to me. In any country successful competitive industries exist only because of government planning and industry assistance mechanisms. I ask honourable senators to look at all the success stories. But such an approach has not been ideologically palatable to conservative governments in Australia. That is why such success has never happened here and why we are now in the mess we are in.

TALK.START.PARA: —You agree with Barry Jones that those measures would not restore employment in manufacturing.

—I will give a personal explanation to Senator Rae some time if he wants it so that he can understand my answers. Let us examine a couple of the industries he mentioned. The three stated objectives of the 1976 motor vehicle plan were as follows: Firstly, maintaining a viable industry producing at high levels of local content; secondly, ensuring consumers' access to reliable economic and reasonably priced vehicles; and thirdly, facilitating desirable structural change to improve the efficiency and competitiveness of the industry. Has that happened? Senator Rae has complained about my record of 10 weeks. Four days after we came into government, I got a call from Broken Hill Proprietary Co . Ltd saying that it was to sack 1,400 people. Eight days after we came into government I got a call from General Motors-Holden's Ltd saying that it was to sack 1,200 people. Are those sackings the responsibility of the Labor Government or are they the responsibility of the failure of past policies? Those who address themselves to that question clearly and fairly can come up with only one answer. The obvious answer is that we have inherited enormous structural problems in industry which have not been addressed before. I thought these would have been the sorts of questions to which Senator Rae might have addressed himself today. I thought he might have asked why, in ten weeks, we have not done what the Opposition failed to do in seven years and before that in 20 years. When I read the terms of the matter of public importance he submitted to the Senate this morning I thought he would speak about why we had not done all these things in ten weeks. But he has not done that at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what happened five years after the objectives of the motor vehicle plan were stated. The Industries Assistance Commission described the situation very well in June 1981 in its report on the motor vehicle industry. It said:

Despite high and rapidly increasing assistance, disruption to the industry has not been avoided. Production and sales, both in aggregate and for particular firms, fluctuated considerably in the 1970s. Domestic production in 1980 was the lowest in a decade. Employment in the manufacturing sector of the industry has declined by about a third since the mid 1970s and major plant closures have occurred. Employment in the motor vehicle distribution and services sector, previously a growth area, has also declined. Profitability of vehicle manufacturers has not been good.

That pattern, of course, is repeated across the spectrum of industries. Within the period of the Fraser Government the results of absence of industry policy were there for all to see. We had a less efficient economy as measured by a wide variety of indicators. Per capita growth in consumption was the lowest of the major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries between 1975 and 1981. Australia's growth rate was 1.4 per cent, well below the OECD average of 2.3 per cent. The only time Australia had a better growth rate was between 1972 and 1975. That was the only time Australia's growth rate was above the OECD average. The same occurred with unemployment in 1975, when Australia's unemployment rate was below the OECD average. By 1977 we had passed the OECD average in respect of both these matters. By the time of the 1983 election our unemployment rate was well above the OECD average and we had growing inflation, growing unemployment and rising interest rates-all at the one time. No wonder Senator Rae did not want to address his mind to some of those questions.

I wish to speak very briefly about our industry policies. First of all I say quite frankly that in spite of Senator Rae's miscellany of quotations-largely out of context-the response of industry bodies to what we have been about has been very favourable indeed. The newsletter of the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures at the end of April stated:

Since its election in March the new Hawke Government also has demonstrated its commitment to maintaining a strong manufacturing sector and the VCM believes the introduction of more effective national policies will continue.

I am told by Senator Rae that all the dreadful things we announced in the economic statement of 21 May are detrimental. Of course, some of them are marginally detrimental to industry but we still retain the investment allowance and we still retain a depreciation allowance regime. In spite of the standards throughout the world in terms of depreciation the Fraser Government took seven years to bring us up to the rest of the industrialised world in terms of its proposals about revising the depreciation regime. This Government has indicated on a number of occasions that it will maintain existing protection programs at a time of massive social distress and dislocation. We are seeking wage moderation. We have indicated our concern about wage restraint since we were elected to government. As the Age commented yesterday, we have maintained a consensus on this issue in spite of the best efforts of the Opposition in this place. The Chamber of Manufactures and other bodies have referred to these matters in similar terms.

Senator Rae mentioned the steel industry. We undertook to provide a development plan for the steel industry. We will do that in the time we have foreshadowed in recent statements. What did the Fraser Government do about the steel industry? It is an industry which shed 15,000 workers in the last 18 months. What did honourable senators opposite do about the steel industry when that process was going on?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing.
—Nothing at all. To use a colloquialism, those workers got the Big A from the Fraser Government.
—I rather thought the IAC inquiry was established. Be fair.

—Oh yes, honourable senators opposite established inquiries into everything during their period of government but they never did anything about the answers they got on any matter. We are developing policies and encouraging industry. We will announce in the Budget context policies for the adoption and the adaption of the development of better technology in Australia. We will be supporting such bodies as the Industrial Design Council of Australia and others which are concerned with better products from manufacturing industry in this country. We are already considering ways of improving the venture and high risk capital market in Australia. A whole series of new policies beneficial to small business will be announced within five months of our election to government-not five years of Fraser Government total neglect.
—Will you let them be on EPAC?
—Senator Rae is concerned about the Economic Planning Advisory Council. Does he want to be on EPAC; is that the point?
—Will small business be on it? I know the Opposition will not be on it because we are excluded from everything, notwithstanding what the Prime Minister said before the election.

—That is quite proper in view of the performance of honourable senators opposite. I do not have time to go through this at length. I will do so at any time Senator Rae wants to bring up a matter of public importance about industry policy and the real issues. I do not intend to waste my time responding to a diatribe of personal invective.
