TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I state that I was not very impressed with the way in which the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) responded to the speech made by Senator Rae in drawing attention to the neglect of the Government in doing something about job opportunities in Australia. The mark of the confidence that the Australian Labor Party has in the Minister was demonstrated by the number of Labor senators who were in the chamber listening to their illustrious leader. Perhaps I should start off in referring to the steel industry by quoting--
—How many were there?

—There are six now. That is a pretty good audience for the standard set by the Minister in his speech. Perhaps those honourable senators were rustled up by the Whip to give the Minister a little additional support. I wish to start off by referring to the steel industry by quoting a leading article in the Australian on Monday, 23 May 1983. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: When the Hawke government came into office a little over 70 days ago, the new Industry and Commerce Minister, Senator John Button, promised a long term plan for the steel industry within 100 days. He has since suggested that the problems in the industry are so complex it might take longer to make a decision.

It should now be apparent that further delays in coming up with a long term plan for recovery are unacceptable. As the Minister with ultimate power in this area, Senator Button must ensure that the tough decisions are made quickly. It is only in that way this country can be assured of a world competitive, viable and profitable steel industry, with all that means for employment in our biggest manufacturing sector.

I recall that during the election campaign the present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, went to South Australia and demonstrated very volubly that he was interested in supporting an Australian steel industry. At the time he accused the Fraser Government of doing nothing about that industry and of making no statements with respect to it. Mr Hawke failed to tell the people of Australia, and South Australia in particular, that as a result of actions taken by the Whitlam Government when it abolished the Tariff Board and introduced the Industries Assistance Commission no government, legally, could make any judgment or decision with respect to any industrial sector in Australia before a draft report from the IAC was presented. That statement made by Mr Hawke shows how the Labor Party misled the community and the electorate of Australia during the election campaign.

During the election campaign a public meeting was held at Whyalla. The Secretary of the Australian Labor Party was in the audience. I was glad that he was present because we were able to tell him something of the development that had taken place under the Fraser Government. The then Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, was there as a speaker. He demonstrated what had been done and what was in prospect for Australia with respect to mineral development, which is most important to the northern part of South Australia and the Northern Territory. During question time the Secretary of the Australian Labor Party rose to his feet and asked: 'What is the Fraser Government going to do about the steel industry?' Senator Sir John Carrick answered him. The Secretary of the Labor Party, not entirely satisfied with the response, rose again and asked: 'In view of the fact that BHP at Whyalla is to reduce its work force to 4,000, what is the Fraser Government going to do about the steel industry?'. I contributed to the answer to the question. I said: 'I will tell you what the Fraser Government is going to do for the steel industry in Whyalla, South Australia'. I said: 'We will build a railway line from Alice Springs to Darwin, a distance of 1,440 kilometres. It will require 150,000 tonnes of steel rail and 2,225,000 sleepers. If it is decided that steel will be used for the sleepers, another 150,000 tonnes of steel will be required from Whyalla'. Furthermore we, as a government, intended to develop the Beverley and Honeymoon uranium deposits. Those two names will be familiar to those people in South Australia who are listening to this debate. Those two projects could have been brought into production within 18 months or so. That would require steel prefabrication in Whyalla.

I also suggested that if the State Labor Government would co-operate with the Fraser Government with respect to uranium enrichment, a uranium enrichment plant could be built in Port Pirie. As a result hundreds of thousands of steel centrifuges could be prefabricated in Whyalla. I added that if the people of South Australia-and Australia-wanted development and job opportunities they should vote for the Fraser Government. If they wanted no development, no support for the steel industry, they should choose the Opposition, in which case it would be their funeral. I think people now appreciate that it could well be their funeral because this Government is not particularly interested in the development of our resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have broken promises.

—On the subject of broken promises, what did the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) say during the election campaign? He promised to provide an immediate reduction in income tax. That did not happen. He promised to retain the tax rebate for home loan repayments. That did not happen. I could mention a long list of broken promises, one of which was his promise that the Government would not abandon the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. Senator Kilgariff has been very indignant about that matter, as has Mr Paul Everingham. They pointed to the fact that the Northern Territory was relying on that project.
—It is to the detriment of South Australia.

—I believe it is to the detriment of the mutual development of the Northern Territory and South Australia and it is in the national interest that that project should proceed. I regret very much that the great hope that was generated by former Prime Minister Fraser when he said that that project would go ahead has now been placed in jeopardy by the recent decision of the razor gang employed by the Labor Government. I was upset about the decision with regard to the Alice Springs-Darwin railway, particularly in view of the fact that it was supported quite strongly by the Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, when he stated a few days before the decision was made that he supported the Alice Springs-Darwin railway as being in the long term interests of the development of this country. He pointed, of course, to the fact that it would generate 1,250 jobs. I believe that is an example of the way in which the Minister for Industry and Commerce has failed miserably to persuade the Government to proceed with that project in the interests of the steel industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the importance of the uranium industry to Australia. This is another area in which the Minister should lend his support in order to recover the ground that has been lost because of the uncertainty existing in mining companies and industries in Australia with respect to the Australian Labor Party policy on this important subject. A headline in the Weekend Australian of 14-15 May states: 'Australia loses ground as Koreans turn to Canada for uranium'. It is very important for people to recognise that Australia has major deposits of uranium. Our deposits are on a par with those in Canada in turns of quality and basic competitiveness. In addition, there are a number of other factors which will favour new Australian producers in competing for satisfactory long term sales contracts. Firstly, we have very large proven resources of uranium and potentially could emerge with the largest resources in the Western world when the Olympic Dam deposit has been more fully evaluated. Our assured and probable resources now stand at about 550,000 tonnes of uranium. Indicated resources at Olympic Dam may increase this by one million tonnes. So, we have in Australia a major resource that ought to be made available for overseas countries.

What does that mean? Can we afford to pass up these uranium-based job opportunities? In South Australia alone, it is quite important. As far as employment is concerned, South Australia is a rich uranium province, and, as a matter of fact, most of the uranium in Australia happens to be in South Australia as well as the Northern Territory. We have a little more than you have up in the Northern Territory, Senator Kilgariff. That is what makes the transport facilities so important to the mutual development of the Northern Territory and South Australia. A uranium industry has the potential to generate several thousand jobs. In South Australia alone, the Honeymoon project and the Beverley project, when pilot stage is completed, would generate between 100 and 200 jobs. Uranium conversion plant would generate 200 to 300 jobs in the pilot stage, and a uranium enrichment plant, during the construction stage, would mean about 600 jobs. The total number of jobs involved in those three projects would be between 900 and 1,000, and, during operation, between 700 and 900. In service industries, between 2,150 and 2,750 jobs would be created. As far as the Olympic Dam is concerned, additionally, in the construction stage, between 9,000 and 18, 000 jobs would be generated, and, during operation, there would be between 2,000 and 3,000 jobs. The service industries applicable to that project would gain between 8,000 and 12,000 jobs.

That is the sort of thing that the Fraser Government would have liked to pursue and to implement, and it would have seen some results with respect to generating new industries and new jobs throughout Australia. But this Government has failed to do it-largely, I think, because of the inertia of the Minister for Industry and Commerce.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is distraction, too. He spends most of his time attacking the Australian Broadcasting Commission, which has nothing to do with his portfolio.

—Senator Button goes into portfolios that have nothing to do with him. He makes extravagant statements about the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, gets himself into hot water, and becomes distracted from the very important role that he should be playing in helping to get Australia back on the road to recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us face the fact that the Fraser Government had those problems. We were coming to grips with them. We introduced capital works programs, which have subsequently been trimmed. We introduced a program of national water resource development, which is the most vital activity if we are to develop Australia beyond the year 2050. National water resources are the most vital element with which we must come to grips on a national basis. If the Government comes up with a proposition to develop a national water resource program, I shall be in total support of that, because I believe that, by the year 2050, our water resources will be fully committed. Unless we do something now, spending not $650m, because I think that the sum ought to be $6.5 billion or more right now, I believe that Australia will go down the drain beyond that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The topic of this matter of public importance covers those problems of industry which are causing loss of both jobs and investment and the failure of the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Senator Button) to take appropriate steps to overcome these problems. I think that we need to look at the causes of loss of jobs and investment not just in the context of what is happening today or what happened last week, or even what has happened in the last couple of months, but how we have arrived at our present position. I think it is not even appropriate to suggest that the causes are just the policies of the previous Liberal-National Party Government, although it is obvious that many people believe that those policies have a lot to do with our present predicament. It is also not appropriate to say that the cause was of the trends in the international economy, which is still in recession and which has caused a world drop in demand for Australian raw materials. Nor is it fair to suggest that the causes were related to the drought , which has been superseded now, tragically, by floods. One might add that we as a parliament have made inadequate preparation for such disasters in this country . Whatever the causes they have resulted in the decline in business profits, high interest rates and some disproportionately high wages and wage increases. Of course, when one is looking at the high wages and the high wage increases in some areas one needs to recognise that this was brought about by the coalition Government abandoning the central wage fixing system and allowing nature to take its course.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is fair to say, when one is looking at all of these causes and the governments this country has endured over the last decade or so, that the people have started to wonder whether the country in fact has been managed at all by its government. For instance, Morgan Gallup polls taken out in October 1982 indicate how people felt in the five years from 1977 to 1982. In 1977 people felt that the Liberal-National Party Government had managed the economy better and the proportion of people who felt that way was 46 per cent compared with 32 per cent who favoured the Australian Labor Party management of the economy. By October 1982 in fact the people were recognising that they were in a tremendous predicament. The polls showed that 37 per cent of people thought the Liberal- National Party managed the economy better, 37 per cent thought Labor could manage the economy better and 26 per cent said that neither party was capable of managing the economy. In other words, the choice was Tweedledum or Tweedledee and preferably neither of those two.

We now have a Government which is caught between two urgent requirements. On the one hand is the need to rescue the economy from its disastrous condition and on the other hand-at times this may be in conflict with the first requirement-is the need to plan and to take responsible long lasting measures, fully planned and fully communicated for the long term recovery and stabilising of Australia's economy. In other words, we have the difficult choice-ad hoc solutions or long term solutions. We have just been through seven years of Liberal ad hockery-the Liberals being the masters of ad hockery in government. Regrettably this matter of public importance is typical of the Opposition's approach to Australia's economic problems. The Opposition wanted the solutions found in the first couple of months of government. It wanted instant solutions imposed upon the people of Australia. The very people who are today criticising the lack of action were, a week ago, criticising the mini-Budget and the mere fact that a mini-Budget was introduced to this Parliament.

The Opposition cannot have it both ways. The Liberal Party does not seem to have had any interest in responsible economic management. There has not been any interest for as long as I have been tuned in to this Parliament, and there does not seem to have been any interest at all judging by the actions of the party even as late as 1982 when it introduced a typical pre-election Budget with the object of having an election a month or so later. That was an election Budget which nearly destroyed this country's economy. The Liberal Party did the same thing with its pre-election jitters for 12 months at a time before each of the last elections. But these were ultimately held after hanging back and pretending to the people of Australia that in the next month or the month after the Australian Democrats would cause of a double dissolution.

So the whole of the economy of this country was left in a state of uncertainty simply because a Prime Minister wanted to hold his back benchers and a few other lobbyists and pressure-groups at bay while he pretended that an election was around the corner. In other words, for seven years we had no direction. We had literally a ship with no one on the bridge-like our aircraft carrier, which served a very valuable, useful, decorative purpose, if that is an important function-a ship unsure of its objectives or its direction. In other words, the officers on the bridge are there for ceremonial purposes only. It has been that way with Australia for the last seven years because nobody has been interested in longer term planning. That is what this matter of public importance today suggests-that we should continue without longer term planning.

I give a little credit to the Australian Labor Party because at least it organised the National Economic Summit Conference. It introduced, produced and presented some economic forecasting models to the people of Australia who have to make key decisions in the near future. It is to be hoped that this process will be repeated next year and in subsequent years and that it was not just a one-off action to win a few friends at the start of Labor's term of office. It has introduced the Economic Planning Advisory Council. Again it is to be hoped that that will be a meaningful body and not just a group of people which will meet, have a chat and let the Government get on with the job without taking any notice of its advice, but there is not yet any commitment to a long term indicative plan by this Government for the country, for the people who have to make the other crunch decisions outside the Government and the Parliament and who should make them within the framework of a direction of the Parliament or the Government of Australia.

It is time that both the Liberal Party and the Labor Party stopped this antagonistic approach which is endemic in this Parliament and which, regrettably , is so typified by this matter of public importance today. The main sporting activity of this Parliament-it does seem to be a blood sport-is to belt the supporters of one's political opponents. The Liberals found great glee in belting the trade unions about the ears, in making scapegoats out of the unemployed with the object of reducing inflation, and in ignoring the plight of small businesses, thereby encouraging the monopolies which put small businesses out of business. The Liberal Government gave no help to legitimate small business, except to some of its Liberal supporters. A typical case is that of its tax avoider friends who were helped in the tax avoidance industry through years of neglect by the previous Government.

On the other hand, Labor has its enemies that it likes to belt about the ears. It seems to have a thing about big business, irrespective of the value of big business to Australia. It even gets stuck into medium and small businesses. Typical of that attitude is its latest tax reform which sweeps up everybody in an attempt to get at tax avoiders. That tax proposal has the effect, because it is so general, of crucifying some innocent people. This approach suggests that people who have made handsome profits will be hit and made to pay back some of those profits irrespective of whether they were genuine tax avoiders or just caught up in the net which, principally, aimed to get the tax avoidance group.

Labor's attitude towards the private health funds is again typical of a government which wants to hit out rather than build and obtain co-operation from important segments of our community. The Government has initiated two measures in regard to the private health insurance funds, an important group which has gained and developed the confidence of the public. One is to leave them out of Medicare and the other is aimed at reducing their reserves over the next six months so that they will be weakened when the next competitive stage of the development of health insurance starts at the beginning of next year. For some reason which escapes my reasoned attention, it does not seem to have any affection for the professional and self-employed people in this country. No support nor sympathy is given to these groups and individuals. The whole approach of both the Liberal and the Labor parties seems to be: Blame someone else, preferably your political opponents. Let us all become a little constructive. Let us take some corrective measures. Instead of nit-picking and engaging in personal attacks in this Parliament, let us try to implement some measures which will stimulate the economy. It seems that there is scope for that , and the Government has recognised the tremendous potential by stimulating the housing industry.

There is a lot more scope, in addition to that housing industry support, if the Government recognises the tremendous potential of sunrise industries, particularly in the new technology and information areas. The Government seems to have recognised that, but we are awaiting with bated breath its job creation programs. It is to be hoped that it gets behind and strongly supports employment oriented industries such as tourism, recreation and again that self-same information industry. It needs to recognise the desperate need for all Australians to be able to share the available work. That will need some changes of attitude by not just the Government but by people out there in the real world who are suffering tremendous traumas from unemployment. This may include new approaches to industrial relations-perhaps reducing some penalty rates, perhaps reducing some hours and perhaps making deals for tax reductions in lieu of pay increases.

Principally I make an appeal to this Government to help small businesses. The potential for massive growth of small, independent, innovative businesses in this country is unlimited provided we recognise their needs, which are disparate , and provided we give this group adequate communications channels to the Government, which have hitherto been lacking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you support our EPAC amendments?

—Let us look at the things that small businesses need, which include some of the things which the Opposition is proposing. Let us try to give them access to low interest finance and to research and development avenues, let us try to protect the inventors and innovators which we produce in this country but then allow to escape overseas because nobody is interested in supporting them. Let us look at the scope for restructuring small businesses so that, instead of getting the worst of all worlds, they can get the best of the partnership, co-operative, private company and public company structures which are available to other structured organisations and corporations. Let us introduce a just and easily understood tax Act. That will not be done necessarily tomorrow or next year, but let us at least work towards it, even if it takes 10 or 15 years, instead of just working on band-aid measures, as all governments seem to have done over the last few decades. It is time for us to sit down together and to try to restructure the tax Act and at least obtain some worthwhile objectives that we can aim for by the start of the next century if not by the end of this one.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us also give small businesses some help with their training requirements- not just training of management and staff but also training in preparation for the new technologies. Let us get rid of that horrendous payroll tax which is making it so difficult for small businesses to put on additional employees. In conclusion, I believe that the solution to Australia's economic problems is bound up in finding ways in which all of us may work together-all doing our share, all planning our share, all planning and working as one nation. Let this Parliament set the example.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering a matter of public importance, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Minister for Industry and Commerce to take any appropriate steps to overcome those problems of industry which are causing loss of both jobs and investment.

I am very sorry that the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) is not here to listen to this debate. Senator Peter Rae, perhaps being a little personal, described him as the Minister for I Don't Know. The fact that he left the chamber as soon as he had completed his speech might, had he still been here , have led Senator Peter Rae to describe him as the Minister for I Don't Care. Nevertheless, on a subject such as this, when the Senate is debating a matter which should be of great importance to the Minister, he certainly should be here to listen to the debate.

The problem is that it is quite clear that the Australian Labor Party does not understand the nature of the problems facing our economy. Senator Jack Evans, in the contribution he has just made, suggested that the Opposition was proposing that the Government should have instant solutions to all the problems. That is not what we are saying. We are saying that the Government must understand the cause of the problems and not take inappropriate action. We suggest that many of the actions that the Government has taken-I will come to this in a moment-are, in fact, quite inappropriate to the problems we have, and that the fundamental problem of our present industrial system is that the profit share is far too low . The share of profit relative to gross non-farm product used to be, traditionally, 14 to 15 per cent. For instance, in successive years from 1978 to 1981 the share was, respectively, 14.7 per cent, 14.5 per cent, 15.2 per cent and 14.3 per cent. But last year, at a time of declining economic activity, the totally unjustified and unaffordable wage increases pushed the share of profit back to 11.8 per cent.

I know that many honourable senators on the Labor Party benches would cheer about that, but if they thought through the consequences of that I think they would not cheer so loudly because profits are the source of investment. All investment directly or indirectly is the result of profits. Out of investment comes efficiency, out of efficiency comes competitiveness and out of competitiveness comes jobs. Governments cannot afford to allow profit share or investment to fall. Governments cannot make investments. They are made only by firms who think they have a chance of making a further profit. If they do not think they have a chance of making a profit they will not invest.

Faced with all this, what did the Government do? One thing that some of us may still remember is that it held an economic summit meeting which was going to solve all of the problems of the economy. Some of what the Government did at that National Economic Summit Conference was good; the fact that it revealed a lot of economic information I think was excellent. I wish we had done it. I am sure we will do it when we get back to power. It is good that that sort of information is available. But, having released that information, the Government ignored its implications. It adopted, by implication-certainly it is outspokenly in favour of it now-a scenario that will do nothing to improve the share of profits, which will do nothing, therefore, to create new jobs. At the Summit it tacitly accepted a wage policy which it is committed, by the prices and incomes accord with the trade union movement, to support before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. What it committed us to is a loss of further jobs and no restoration of profits. I repeat: Out of profits comes investment, out of investment comes efficiency; out of efficiency comes competitiveness; and, finally, we get more jobs. If the Government does not see that sequence it has no hope of rectifying the serious problems which our economy faces at the moment.
What else did the Government do? It has talked a lot about the importance of the new technology. Senator Button, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, said at the Summit Conference:

We have, however, to direct our energies to the question of modernising our industrial base and expanding into growth activities involving both the manufacturing and service industries. Government policies will be strongly directed to this end.

But are they? I give one example which shows that the Government is doing exactly the opposite; that is, the abolition of group taxation deductions. The previous Fraser Government, in its last Budget, introduced group taxing for industries such as the steel industry. Group taxing allows an industry to offset profits in one division-in the case of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, for instance, the oil division-against losses in another division, thereby providing funds for modernising the loss areas to make them efficient and competitive. BHP planned to spend the $2,400m profits made by the oil division to modernise its steel division. This taxation plan has been scrapped, very unwisely, by the present Government. The result is that these companies will wind down their investment. This decision by the Government is not rational. It was done in direct contrast to its claimed economic objectives.

What else does the Government do? It scraps the water resources program. Australia is the driest continent. If any country needs to devote resources to conserving water it is Australia. As Senator Jessop noted earlier, the Government has scrapped the Alice Springs-Darwin railway, which would have resulted in a considerable demand for steel from Whyalla. The Government is dithering all the time about what is to happen about uranium, an area of activity which could provide many jobs. Again, as Senator Jessop has pointed out , while the Government dithers potential customers are going elsewhere and investment will dry up. People will not invest if they do not know which way the Government is going to jump. I repeat, many jobs are involved. The Chief Minister for the Northern Territory estimated that the mining of uranium could provide 60,000 jobs in the Territory. That figure is probably high, but nevertheless a substantial number of jobs would be provided if proper development were allowed of this key resource to the world economy.

Senator Jack Evans mentioned the importance of stimulating small business activity. The Government is to set up, in the same style as the Summit, an Economic Planning Advisory Council, EPAC, but again it will represent big business, big government and big unions. Small business does not get a look in. I find detestable this system whereby these big groups can decide the economic outlook for all of us. I hope, in view of what Senator Jack Evans has said, that he will support the Liberal Party amendment seeking small business representation on EPAC. When we move it I hope that we will have the Australian Democrats' support for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will.

—I thank the honourable senator; that is excellent. I hope that we will see his vote on the line when the moment arrives. Small business contributes a major share of the Australian economy and must have some input to the framework for the future of our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I have referred to what the Government has done. I suggest that all of the things it has done will prove to be negative and harmful to recovery. The Government has no plan. Perhaps it cannot have a plan because it has not yet seen what the problem is. Until one understands the problem there is no way in which one can act coherently to overcome it. What is the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, doing? Senator Peter Rae spent some little time in describing the way in which the Minister is dithering, the way in which he does not seem to know the answers to any of the questions that really confront him. In that regard, I agree with Senator Peter Rae that the Minister seems to spend more time on communications for which he has no real ministerial responsibility than he does on the key areas with which he should be concerned.

We have no clear directions about tariffs. We do not really know what the Government's decision is to be or what its attitude is to be. It has taken no action on dumping procedures. In reply to a question asked of the Minister during the hearings of Senate Estimates Committee A, the Minister said:
A departmental review of dumping is taking place. I do not know whether it is true to say that we are considering further initiatives.

That seems to be a very inadequate statement on the subject of dumping, which is causing enormous damage to many Australian industries. Whatever attitude one might have on the effect on the Australian economy of varying levels of tariffs, I know of no one who supports dumping, which is malicious, damaging and destructive. To have the Minister say: 'I do not know whether it is true to say that we are considering further initiatives', in giving evidence to a Senate committee seems to indicate more of a hands-off rule than one could possibly justify. No decision has been taken on dumping.

The Minister is also trying to press employers to retain more labour than they can economically employ. I ask honourable senators to think of the consequences. As far as I can gather from what the Minister has said, he is suggesting that BHP should have kept on the 25,000 men that it has shed in the last year or 18 months. But what would be the consequences if it did that? The steel industry would not sell any more steel as a result of keeping on more employees. The company would be bankrupt. Rather than force firms to keep on labour that they cannot usefully employ, the Government should create a climate in which there is a growing economy so that such people can be usefully employed. If the Government forces firms into financial difficulties in order to keep on labour that they neither need nor want, those firms will finish up bankrupt and all of their employees, rather than merely some, will then be out of work. Firms must adjust their labour force to the needs of their market. It is the Government's job to encourage expansion, new markets and new jobs, not to force firms to hold unwanted employees in declining industries.

I understand the Minister has accepted that employment in the manufacturing industry is almost certain to decline. That is true. I think changing technology will have that result. But the Government has not looked at the consequences of that happening. It should be looking at how more people will be employed in the service industries. Yet, has the Government taken action on one of the biggest bars to employment in the service industry, penalty rates? One Minister mentioned penalty rates-he was the Minister who also mentioned koala bears-and he was immediately slapped down by his own party. The Government is not prepared to touch this matter although it knows that this is one of the biggest bars to the shift of employment into the service areas.

The Government has not done anything-I am bound to say it may do something in the Budget, though I doubt it-about payroll tax. That is a very big disincentive to employment, particularly in small businesses. It has not even initiated anything-I hoped it would have by now-to look at the very damaging rackets that are being worked in workers compensation with the consequence that premiums are sky high. Again, this is a strong disincentive for employers to take on people. I wish this Government would talk to the Victorian Government, which is planning dismissal procedures such that it will be almost impossible to discharge employees. The consequence will not be that more people will stay in work. The consequence will be that employers will be very reluctant to take on staff if they know they will not be able to dismiss them if they cannot perform.

This is all just plain muddleheadedness. It is an example of what Mr Peacock has repeatedly described as Hawkespeak-that is, saying one thing and doing the opposite. All the things that I have listed are the exact opposite of what the Government was talking about. You will remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, that during the election campaign we heard a great deal about consensus and about bringing Australia together. Consensus in economic terms seems to mean decision by small functional groups-the fascist system. Big business, big unions and big government get together. They agree and that is called consensus. That is not what consensus is about, or not what it should be about. The Labor Party talked about bringing Australia together. The first major action of this Government in bringing Australia together was to introduce measures which would be the most divisive since Federation. Bringing Australia together indeed! What this Government did during the election campaign was to promise much. So far it has delivered nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —For about the fourth time in two weeks the Senate is facing a somewhat pathetic matter of public importance introduced by the Opposition. I often wonder whether any honourable senators opposite believe in reincarnation. If they do I am sure they will all reappear as great vultures in Serengeti National Park. Senator Peter Rae began by quoting a nursery rhyme. Senator Button very aptly pointed out that it was the only substantive part of his speech. Having heard the three Opposition speakers, I was reminded of the three blind mice. They have, in fact, an absurd expectation of what any one Minister or any government can achieve in 77 days. This matter of public importance is aimed at Senator Button. Senator Button has been a Minister for 72 days; he was sworn in 72 days ago. To expect any Minister or any government to solve any problem within 77 days is a bit much, but to expect Ministers to solve the problems handed to the Labor Government by an absolutely hopeless Liberal government is to expect too much.

SPEECH.PARA: Before taking any action it is necessary to identify the problems. Senator Button has been assiduously applying himself to doing that in the last 10 weeks. He has been assessing what the problems are in Australian industry rather than shooting from the hip. If Senator Button had come into this chamber, having been a Minister for a week, and said 'We will do these 135 things' there would be a matter of public importance stating that the Minister was shooting from the hip and was making statements and decisions without proper consideration. Honourable senators have to understand the problems that we have inherited. I ask them to look at the figures for 1981-82 when exports remained constant. In that period while honourable senators opposite were in government imports went up by 21 per cent. In normal times industry utilisation is between 95 per cent to 100 per cent. At the moment, as a result of the legacy that we inherited from those opposite, it is 70 per cent. in areas such as textiles it is down to 40 per cent .

The bulk of our proposals to deal with these problems will, quite obviously, come in the first Hawke Budget when we will see and debate what we will do to solve some of these problems. For example, the first need, I think, is to get co -operation between employers and employees. A good example of that occurred with the metal trades on 7 April when Senator Button took that very important step of encouraging them to make joint approaches-rather than individual ones-to the Government and discuss the matter. Specific industry recovery in any event will occur only in the context of a general economic recovery. This is achievable only through macroeconomic planning. The Government has already takens steps in this regard. The steps taken so far include the holding of an economic summit, something the Fraser Government refused to do for seven years.

Mr Deputy President, you commented on what a wonderful thing it was to have all the economic facts out in the open. That is a latter-day conversion, at least on behalf of most of the Opposition. When none of the Treasury forecasts were released, when none of the facts were put on the table for every Australian to make up his or her mind and when, as Senator Walsh would say, a former discredited Liberal Treasurer is informed by the Senate of a projected deficit does he tell the public? Of course he does not; he just runs to the Prime Minister who puts the lid on the whole thing. We have had the National Economic Summit Conference. We have prepared the way for the August Budget with a May economic statement which tackled areas that the Liberal Party never had the guts or the foresight to even look at. We are looking at recreating centralised wage fixing so that we do have a wage fixation system in this country. We do not leave it to the market forces. We do not suddenly abolish indexation without any thought of what will follow. We are looking at a proposed pricing authority which has been given at least qualified endorsement by the Australian Industries Development Association. Finally, the energetic approach to new industries, especially those espoused by the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, is under way. The draft report of the Australian Scientific Industry Association states:

One fact is irrefutable: we cannot continue to maintain, let alone improve, our standard of living by doing what we have been doing during the past two decades. Reform is not and never will be a pleasant process. It is going to cause economic dislocations. However, the alternative, which is to do nothing, is far worse.

Let us look at the most recent indicators on where industry is going, what its prospects are and at the AIDA statement issued on 4 April 1983. The AIDA carried out a survey of 60 large Australian mining and manufacturing companies. This April attitude presents a rather stark contrast to what it was in the previous December. At the end of the 1983 first quarter the AIDA states:
Reduction rates in general were proceeding at a lower level significant reductions having been achieved in the second half of 1982.

The AIDA in its outlook says that from April to September 1983 32 per cent of non-mining companies expect an upturn in sales. That was compared with 23 per cent in the December 1982 survey. Some 46 per cent of non-mining companies expect static sales compared with 21 per cent the previous December. Only 24 per cent expect a downturn in sales whereas the previous December the figure was 55 per cent. Labor has been in government one month and already there are expectations of an improved performance in sales. At the beginning of April 1983 78 per cent of non-mining companies surveyed perceived the economic downturn as having bottomed out. Today we have heard a number of attacks on the Government by born-again senators opposite. Suddenly when they are in Opposition they can see how easy it is to solve the country's problems. I think it is relevant to look at the Liberals record in this regard. We had, as Minister for Industry and Commerce for some five years, Sir Phillip Lynch. Admittedly he was not appointed to that position in the most salubrious circumstances. He had to stand down as Treasurer over the Stumpy Gully affair. When the then Prime Minister had the opportunity to reappoint him as Treasurer, he was thought of so highly that he was moved to the industry and commerce portfolio. The current and now discredited Liberal leader replaced him after he had been Minister for five years.

During the time Sir Phillip Lynch was Minister he visited China, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Kenya and Italy. He went back to Italy. He then went to China again , to the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Japan, India, Switzerland and to the United Kingdom again. He went to Europe in general. Then he went to the United States again. He went to Switzerland and India again, to Switzerland yet again and to Japan again. This is by no means a complete list. We had a Minister for Industry and Commerce representing the Liberal Party, who was supposed to be solving the problems but who was almost a constant tourist. He went overseas time and time again. I wonder how many jobs were lost while he was away on these junkets?

After five years of failure Lynch resigned having achived nothing to reconstruct industry in this country. I would have thought that five years was a fair enough time in which to achieve something. But there was total and utter failure. Sir Phillip Lynch will be remembered for two things when the history books are writen and he is assessed. Firstly, he will be remembered for his incompetence as a Minister, marked by 100,000 jobs lost in manufacturing industry. Secondly, during his last year in office I suppose he will be remembered for his intense loyalty to his Liberal leaders, provided they retained the numbers. He is now off mismanaging the Reserve Bank of Australia and I feel sorry for that institution. However, as I said, we had him in Industry and Commerce for five years.

The matter of public importance contains an expectation that Senator Button should have achieved major progress in the area of industry reconstruction. Senator Button has been in office for 77 days. However, the Opposition today has failed to sustain the case that he has not done so. I think the matter of public importance flatters Senator Button almost too much. It expects him to have solved in 70 days the problems that the previous Liberal Government had seven years to deal with. The matter of public importance raised by Senator Peter Rae implicitly acknowledges, albeit unwittingly, that Senator Button has immense capacity and intelligence and has such an interest in the area that one would expect of him that he would have tackled and solved these problems in respect of which Senator Rae's colleagues were pathetic failures. Thus, by raising this matter of public importance, Senator Rae, has, in my view, unwittingly paid Senator Button a compliment.

I think we have to ask the Opposition some questions if Senator Button is expected to solve these problems in 77 days. I ask honourable senators to cast their minds back because the previous incumbent of this position, the present Leader of the Liberal Party, had 145 days in which to solve the crisis that faced Australian manufacturing industries. The then Minister for Industry and Commerce had 145 days in office. During those 145 days more jobs were lost in industry than had been lost in any similar period going back to the Great Depression. Let me give one example. According to figures collected by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in January relating to projected business investment, under a continued Liberal Government investment looked like being 20 per cent less in 1983-84 than in the current financial year. We are still feeling the effect of these policies and more people are still losing their jobs . A lot of the blame can be sheeted back to the previous Minister for Industry and Commerce. That person, not being able to cope with that position and, in my view, not being particularly interested in the fate of ordinary Australians, has , I have to admit, now been promoted to an even more awful job. He now leads a rather querulous, bankrupt and 'second eighteen' Liberal Party. He could not handle the job of Minister for Industry and Commerce. Maybe handling the job of Leader of the Liberal Party is a lot easier. He had to appoint 30 shadow Ministers just to cover our 27 Ministers. When honourable senators opposite were in government, 22 shadow Ministers sufficed to cover the then Government's 27 Ministers. In fact, we used to lap the then Government with 22 shadow Ministers. Yet, the Opposition has 30 shadow Ministers to try to cover our 27 Ministers.

I want to know what policies the Opposition has. After all, it is the loyal Opposition to Her Majesty's Government. What policies does it have? Can members of the Opposition say what they are? They cannot. If they were to do so they would look like they had undergone a latter-day conversion; it would look like, having been in government for seven years and done nothing, that they had suddenly come up with all the answers. That is not good enough. Senator Peter Rae is now, I understand, shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce. I hope over the next two years he will apply himself diligently and come up with an alternative set of policies which he can put to the electorate. I wish him luck that this time round he will not be a bridesmaid again and if he does win government he will become a Minister, but we have no guarantee of that.

I listened to Senator Jack Evans. He made many constructive comments that industry should be restructured. Unfortunately the difficulty with any of the suggestions by the Australian Democrats is that they are never in a position to put those suggestions into effect. They come up with many ideas which are never costed and never balanced against other ideas. They are always in favour of reducing a whole range of government income measures and always in favour of a whole range of government expenditure measures. Unfortunately they cannot balance the two.

This matter of public importance debate today has been the worst of a series we have had in this place. Members of the Opposition have failed to sustain that the Minister's performance is a matter of public importance. They have failed to put the alternative case. They have fairly vindictively attacked the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). But I do not have to defend him; he did that fairly well. I believe that as the debate started with a nursery rhyme it could well end in that way. I think it reflects that the Opposition is just floundering and struggling around trying to disrupt things. It might be better-I know it is gratuitous advice from a novice such as I-for the Opposition if it started debating the important legislation that is still confronting us and making constructive comments here rather than coming up with such pathetic arguments.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRADE AND COMMERCE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Australian Fishing Industry

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Senator Coleman:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce during the period in which the investigation into the fishing industry took place. First and foremost, I would like to thank the Committee and the staff for the time devoted to that inquiry. We had various problems during the Committee hearings because of the time involved and the changes of both Committee members and Committee staff. I make this plea to those who are responsible: What we need is staff who will be given a chance to settle in during an inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: I found the inquiry to be a most valuable experience. I visited between 50 and 60 fishing ports around Australia. I spoke with hundreds of fishermen in various places and I attended dozens of association and co-operative meetings. When I went to a fishing port I found it a little disconcerting that when I said I was from the Government it did not bring me much credit. The relationship between the industry, the Government and the Department of Primary Industry was generally less than favourable. Fishermen Australia-wide came up with the same problem. They did not feel they had sufficient input into what was happening to their industry. It was found that there was totally inadequate reporting from the Government and the Department back to the industry. I was making a few notes a couple of days ago when I realised that a few weeks back I had received a document headed 'The Policy and Practice in Fisheries Management'. It reached me in April 1983. The document was printed in 1982 and the subject matter related to a seminar that was held in Melbourne, which I attended, in February 1980. It is my opinion that a document that comes out three years after the event is really of little value.

It was felt generally that there was a lack of departmental expertise. Not enough people in the Department had very much knowledge of the industry's point of view. At this stage, I do not wish to particularise except to mention one person who has recently left. I thank Con Keating, who was in the Department during the inquiry, very much for the co-operation and expertise he exhibited and I wish him well in his move to another area.

By and large, the industry is regarded around Australia as being, in many ways, nearly a peasant industry. People do not regard fishing as terribly important. But about 20,000 people are engaged in the catching area and about 5,000 in the processing area. In one form or another, there are about 20,000 boats. The value of the catch is about $330m, which makes the fishing industry a fairly large enterprise when compared with other primary industries. One of the problems is that it has had almost uncontrolled growth. For instance, the value of boats in 1968-69 was listed at $64m but by 1978-79 it was listed at $413m. Most of these were big boats with a high catching capacity and high capitalisation.

I presented the report to the then Deputy President in January. I sent copies to all the people around Australia who had given evidence and had shown an interest and I also wrote to them all asking them for their comments. Honourable senators might ask: Did I get them? I certainly did. I got letters and calls from all over Australia. I suppose that I have had about 120 to 150 replies in one form or another. Generally, the replies and the comments on the report were fairly similar. They established that a national policy was universally required and that it was absolutely important to the industry to be able to plan ahead. After the Industries Assistance Commission report comes down, the industry requires a national conference. This has been discussed and I hope it is carried through. The fishermen want representation at the decision-making level and compulsory funding for management research and sales promotion. They do not seem keen on having a centralised, domestic marketing body but they want an improvement on what they have and they want to discuss this in a manner that will clean up and improve the industry.

Several people said that they wanted funding and representation but not a statutory authority. When I was able to discuss it with them and point out to them that the only way in which they could have representation and compulsory funding was via a national authority they all agreed, with the exception of about one of two cases, that a statutory authority was necessary. Similarly, they said that they did not see how yet another advisory body, as has been proposed from another source, would give them anything more than they have now.

The matter of the 200-mile zone was discussed very largely in the early stages of the Committee. By and large it has not helped the industry. It created an over-expectation which was never achieved. It is an aspect on which there is still quite a lot of work to do. The industry and its administration are far from out of trouble yet. Already too much has been invested; there are too many boats; and there has been too much effort. A reduction in this regard is required. I think the industry can do this. The industry can make these decisions. I believe that, with a bit of government assistance only, the industry can carry it through. The Committee report commented on surveillance, how poor this was, the lack of co-ordination between the various surveillance bodies around Australia, and the inefficiency of the types of planes and vessels that are being used to carry out this surveillance. A lot of thought has to be given to surveillance.

There are problems in the various fisheries which I will not take time to go through. Again, the fishermen themselves can make the suggestions that would put these matters right. They want to make these suggestions and they want to be a part of the decision-making. They do not want to have to fight the Department over it; they want to work with the Government.

Import replacement is a very big item. What we found from this inquiry was that while the industry was catching fish it was not catching fish of the type the market required and it was not presenting the fish as the market wanted; it was not sufficiently market oriented. It is important that the industry should take the trouble to do what the consumer wants, and that is not being done sufficiently at the moment.

I should like to make a special mention of the Australian Fishing Industry Council. AFIC has done a tremendous job over the last few years. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, during the passage of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1982, Senator Peter Rae raised several matters in Committee on 15 December 1982. They are recorded in Hansard at pages 3574 to 3580. His concerns related to provisions of the Bill affecting liability for any losses incurred by the Australian Wheat Board in its futures trading transactions as in clause 5, alterations to the Wheat Board's financial powers as in clauses 6, 7, 8 and 16, and a change in procedure for the remuneration of the Wheat Board's authorised receivers as in clause 17. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has agreed to provide responses to Senator Rae's questions and I now present them to the Senate on Mr Kerin's behalf. I seek leave to have the responses incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The responses read as follows-
Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1982
Clause 5:

This clause amended section 12 of the Wheat Marketing Act 1979 to enable the AWB to operate on future markets in order to minimise risks associated with wheat sales and borrowings for financing the Board's operations. Such transactions are to be undertaken within guidelines approved by the Minister for Primary Industry.

Senator Rae wished to know who would be liable for any losses arising out of AWB future trading, either within or outside the guidelines; whether the Attorney-General is of the opinion that the individual AWB Board members would be responsible for any such losses; and whether the Attorney-General had advised this Department of his opinion.

The use of the term 'losses' can be misleading in relation to futures activities involving hedging operations. In these circumstances, any futures activities are matched against equivalent cash activities, for example, in relation to a specific parcel of wheat. Any gains or losses sustained on the futures part of the operation should be offset by losses or gains on the cash transactions.

The outcome of the trading on the futures and cash wheat markets will be incorporated into the calculations of the Net Pool Return Rate (NPRR) under the Guaranteed Minimum Price (GMP) arrangements when the futures transactions are conducted within the futures guidelines approved by the Minister for Primary Industry. Therefore, in cases where the NPRR of a season is above the GMP price, the results would be directly reflected in the returns to growers whilst in cases where the NPRR is below the GMP price there will be a call on the Government's guarantee, to the extent of the difference between the GMP and the NPRR for the entire season.

Should the AWB conduct futures transactions outside the approved guidelines, the situation is that, under S (9) (3) (h), in calculating the net pool return no account shall be taken of the results of those transactions in calculating the NPRR. If the NPRR so calculated were less than the GMP the effect of the exclusion of futures transactions conducted outside the guidelines would ensure that those transactions would not be included in the calculation of the call on the Government's guarantee. In these circumstances growers' entitlement from the AWB would be the net return from the pool, including the effect of the transaction conducted outside the Minister's guidelines, plus the amount of the Government's guarantee calculated on the basis of excluding any transactions conducted outside the guidelines. The legislative requirements to enable the AWB , and ultimately the wheatgrowers, to bear such a ''loss'' would have to be addressed should the circumstances arise.

Senator Rae also asked whether the individual Board members of the AWB would be liable for losses arising from futures trading by the AWB. The Minister will seek a formal opinion on this matter from Attorney-General's particularly on the effect of Section 38 of the Act.
Clause 6

This clause amended section 12 of the Wheat Marketing Act 1979 to enable the AWB to establish specific purpose financial reserves from the 1982-83 season onwards and deduct moneys from sales of wheat and wheat products for those reserves. Any such deductions of moneys for reserves are excluded from the GMP arrangement.

Senator Rae stated that the provision legalises the Ceres House reserve which was identified by the Auditor-General as an illegal reserve; and asked why the Minister for Primary Industry is not required to approve the creation of financial reserves.

With respect to the Ceres House reserve, the new provision does not legalise the current reserve as specific purpose reserves under the amended Act may only be created and funded from the sale proceeds of wheat and wheat products from the 1982-83 season onwards. The Ceres House reserve was created and funded prior to the 1982-83 season, and the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department has been sought on an appropriate method of quitting that reserve. This is not to say that a reserve cannot now be created by the Board for purposes such as the provision of AWB accommodation.

The AWB's actions in setting up and funding reserves have not been made subject to ministerial approval; instead the specific reserves and their purpose must be disclosed in the Board's Annual Report (clause 16). Moreover the flow of funds out of the reserves are subject to Ministerial approval, if they are expended through contracts worth more than $100,000.
Clauses 7 and 8:

Clause 7 amends section 21 of the Act to enable the AWB to enter into optional arrangements for payment of the GMP entitlement to growers who deliver their wheat to or on behalf of the Board. Details of payment options are to be agreed upon between the individual grower and the AWB subject to equity between growers being preserved.
Clause 8 amends section 22 (5) of the Act to remove the constraint that advances to growers on account of the final payment must be approved by the Minister.

Senator Rae asked why requirements for Ministerial approval had not been included or had been removed in these provisions. The legislative provisions provide statutory criteria for any agreement made between individual growers and the Board. In these circumstances it will be a matter for the Auditor-General to be satisfied that statutory criteria are met in any of the agreements so made and to report to the Parliament if there are instances where he is not satisfied .

The approval by the Minister of advances to growers on account of the final payment is unnecessary, since these advances can only be made after the Board has funded its borrowings for that season. The Minister's approval is still required for the essential elements of each pool, namely the determination of both the GMP and the final pool payments.
Clause 17:

This clause amends section 55 of the Act so that remuneration by the AWB for costs incurred by its authorised receivers will be at specified rates as determined by the authorised receiver from time to time and in accordance with remuneration agreements between the authorised receivers and the AWB in existence at the time.

Senator Rae queried why the provision changes the previous arrangements so that the authorised receivers now determine the price to be charged without necessarily obtaining AWB agreement to the determined rate and stated that the AWB is not in a position to obtain an alternative service if it believes the rates of charge are unreasonable and that the bases of the charges are not subject to an audit to determine whether the rates are reasonable. He also queried whether there are any means by which the AWB may recover any overpayments to authorised receivers.

The rates set by the authorised receivers and charged by the AWB are determined in accordance with the procedures and legal requirements of the States. Those procedures and legal requirements vary from State to State, but each has a statutory responsibility to a Minister of the State. The legislative provisions in each State place the responsibility for setting the rates on the receiver and the growers in the State.

The AWB accepts the rates as determined by each authorised receiver under these arrangements. The amendment was designed to overcome the difficulty in the previous Act raised by the Auditor-General concerning the inability of the Board to ''agree'' to rates the setting of which is the responsibility of the authorised receivers. The authorised receivers' financial affairs are scrutinised by the relevant State auditors and made public through their Annual Reports. As the rates are set in advance, the question of overpayments does not arise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now wish to refer to certain matters, on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industry, relating to the Australian Wheat Board. On 25 March 1983 the Minister granted a request by the Australian Wheat Board to extend the reporting period for its 1981-82 annual report from 31 March 1983 to 31 May 1983 . The financial statements have generally been late in presentation and have been accompanied by qualifications by the Auditor-General. Naturally, therefore, the Minister is keeping a close watch on the Board's attempts to overcome its problems. He has held discussions with the Auditor-General and with the Chairman of the Board to ascertain the progress which has been made. In addition, he has continued the practice of his predecessors whereby the Board provides reports to him on a quarterly basis on the progress made in overcoming the Auditor-General's qualifications. The Minister has asked me to inform the Parliament that in his opinion the Board is making significant progress. This view has been confirmed in his discussions with the Auditor-General and Sir Leslie Price, the Board Chairman.

For example, one of the most serious qualifications of the Auditor-General has been that in his opinion the Board 'does not have proper accounts and records as required under section 63F of the Audit Act'. The basic reason for this qualification has been the Board's lack of procedures and controls to ensure the accuracy of information recorded on a pool basis, particularly in relation to stock handled by the authorised receivers. To overcome this the Board has recently resorted to itself establishing a task force to document the systems and procedures employed by each authorised receiver. The Board hopes that this exercise, which has now been completed, will provide the basis for the removal of the qualification. The Minister wishes to make it clear that the Board requested the second extension because the Auditor-General's Office had informed the Board:

. . . that there is no possibility that the Auditor-General's report upon the Board's 1982 financial statements, which were signed on 12 May 1983, will be available to the Minister by 31 May 1983. The Audit Office is, of course, most conscious of the Board's desire to report formally to the Minister on its operations as soon as possible, and is anxious to finalise the audit report. It is our view that a further 60 day extension of the time for the submission of the Board's report to the Minister ought to be sought.

The Minister therefore decided to grant the second extension because the delay had been caused mainly by the action which the Board has been taking to improve its accounts and because the request is fully supported by the Auditor-General. The Minister gives his assurance that he will continue to monitor closely the Board's performance in this area and will keep the Parliament fully informed of developments.
