PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Family Law Act 1975.
Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a fist time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The law reform policy released before the election stated that a top priority for a Labor government would be the introduction of a Bill to propose overdue reforms of the Family Law Act. The Family Law Amendment Bill 1983 is the fulfilment of that promise. Any government that cares for people and is concerned to minimise unhappiness and social conflict must give paramount consideration to family law matters. Family law affects more Australians-adults and children-than any other single area of law. When marriages break down, for whatever reason, every effort must be made to ensure speedy resolution of differences with the minimum of trauma and expense and the maximum possible benefit to all parties.

I believe it is overwhelmingly accepted that the Family Law Act was a landmark in social legislation. It was a great Labor achievement and is one of the enduring legacies of former Senator Murphy's time as Attorney-General. Its removal of the concept of matrimonial fault from the law relating to this most complex of human relationships was a revolutionary advance. Its establishment of the single ground, no fault divorce must on no account be jeopardised. Free from the burden of attributing fault, the Family Court can now concentrate on being satisfied as to the fact of marriage breakdown and on deciding the most equitable distribution of property, the proper level of maintenance and, of overwhelming importance, the best possible arrangements for the welfare of any children of the marriage It will be recalled that the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act recommended that there should be no change in the grounds of divorce, and that is the Government's firmly held view, as reflected in this Bill.

Social legislation like the Family Law Act must, however, be kept constantly under review to ensure that it reflects changing social conditions and continues to achieve maximum public benefit. It is now nearly five years since the Joint Select Committee was appointed to conduct a comprehensive inquiry into the operation of the Family Law Act. It is almost three years since the Committee reported to the former Attorney-General, Senator Durack. The Committee made a large number of important recommendations which, regrettably, are only now being implemented. The Family Law Council, the Law Council of Australia, the judges of the Family Court and hundreds of individual Australians have made constructive suggestions for reform to the Family Law Act and the operation of the Family Court, many of which are taken up in this Bill. The primary point of reference has, nevertheless, been the admirable report of the Joint Select Committee, the majority of whose recommendations are being adopted, administratively or by this Bill.

The Bill I introduce today will implement wholly or in part some 37 recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. A number of other recommendations have been implemented administratively. It will be recalled that the former Attorney-General introduced a Family Law Amendment Bill in October 1981, the purpose of which was to implement some recommendations of the Joint Select Committee. However, when Parliament was prorogued for the election in March this year that Bill had not even progressed beyond the stage of the second reading debate. In view of the long history of these amendments, I should make clear that all the amendments that were contained in the 1981 Bill and the further amendments foreshadowed by Senator Durack in March 1982 have been included in this Bill.

We have decided to introduce a number of further important amendments, some of which were recommendations of the Joint Select Committee, others of which implement more recent recommendations of the Family Law Council. In particular, this Bill implements a number of recommendations of the Watson Committee, a committee of the Family Law Council which examined in depth a number of matters arising from the Joint Select Committee's recommendations concerning guardianship, custody and wardship proceedings. I will draw attention to these amendments during my remarks. The amendments contained in the Bill fall broadly into three classes: Those which expand the jurisdiction of the Family Court; those which relate to the structure and procedures of the Family Court; and those which affect the substantive law applied in courts exercising jurisdiction under the Act. Mr Deputy President, given time constraints and the considerable length of the remaining portion of the second reading speech, which deals in detail with each one of those three areas, I believe it might suit the convenience of the Senate were I to seek leave at this stage to have the remainder of the speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows-
Expansion of Jurisdiction of Family Court

I will deal first with those amendments that propose an expansion of the jurisdiction under the Act to deal with proceedings concerning children and matrimonial property. It will be recalled that in recent years there has been increasing criticism from the High Court and other courts regarding what the Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs, in the 1982 case of Fountain v. Alexander described as: 'the confusion and inconvenience that is caused by the fact that jurisdiction in cases relating to the custody of children is divided between State and federal courts'. As the Chief Justice went on to point out, this situation causes not only uncertainty for litigants but also costs to mount and delays to increase.

It was therefore to be hoped, indeed expected, that when the State and federal law makers of Australia gathered in Adelaide a month or so ago for the Constitutional Convention there would be unanimous support for the proposal for a constitutional amendment to permit the Commonwealth to legislate for the guardianship, custody and maintenance of all children.

Regrettably, however, support for the proposed constitutional amendment was not forthcoming at the Convention from Senator Durack and his Liberal colleagues, notwithstanding that the proposal had originated with and been promoted by the previous Government and by Senator Durack as Attorney-General. All the Convention achieved, as a result, was to bury the idea alive, by referring it to a Standing Committee of the Convention for further, quite unnecessary, consideration. There thus remain two classes of children in Australia: Those who have the benefit of federal law and a specialist court emphasizing conciliation, and those who do not.

In these circumstances the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee that the Commonwealth legislate to the full extent of its powers in relation to children and matrimonial property, assume a new urgency. The amendments in the Bill which implement those recommendations seek to reduce, as far as constitutionally possible, the existing jurisdictional divisions in family law, and must be regarded as the most important in the Bill.

In relation to the jurisdiction under the Family Law Act to deal with proceedings concerning children, this Bill proposes a three-way expansion. First , it proposes an expansion in the class of children with respect to whom guardianship, custody and like proceedings may be brought, to include not only ( as at present) the natural and adopted children of both parties to the marriage but also:
a child adopted since the marriage by either party to the marriage with the consent of the other;
a child of either party to the marriage who is ordinarily a member of their household;
a child born to the parties (or in certain circumstances to one of them) as a result of either artificial insemination by donor or in-vitro fertilizaton; and
a child who while not the child of either party, has been treated by the parties as a member of their family and who is ordinarily a member of their household (Clause 4).

Secondly, the Bill will enable a person who is not a party to the marriage-for example a grandparent-to initiate proceedings under the Act against one or both parties to the marriage in relation to a child of the marriage. At the present time, where a third party wishes to institute such proceedings he or she must do so in a State court under State law unless the child has previously been the subject of proceedings under Commonwealth law. The Bill seeks to remedy this anomalous situation (Sub-clause 3 (1)).

The third way in which the Bill will expand the Act's jurisdiction concerning children is to permit proceedings concerning the welfare of a child. These amendments reflect the Government's decision to implement the Watson Committee recommendation that the Family Law Act be amended to enable orders to be made for the protection of the welfare of a child of a marriage, thereby investing courts exercising jurisdiction under the Act with a power similar to the wardship power of the State Supreme Courts. The Joint Select Committee favoured the conferral of a wardship jurisdiction on courts exercising jurisdiction under the Act. The Watson Committee, however, concluded that while the substance of the jurisdiction was highly desirable, the terminology or concept of wardship, which the Committee described as 'archaic', ought to be abolished.

In accordance with the Watson Committee's views, the Bill does not use the language of wardship but instead provides that proceedings concerning the welfare of a child of a marriage that involve at least one of the parties to the marriage are a matter, indeed an exclusive matter, for the Family Court. Although the relevant amendments in the Bill will prevent the State Supreme Courts from exercising ward of court powers in proceedings concerning a child of a marriage and involving a party to the marriage, I would stress that the Commonwealth does not propose to intrude into the area that is commonly termed State child welfare law. The relevant provisions of the Bill make this clear ( Sub-clause 3 (1)). At the same time, the Bill contains a provision to enable a court exercising jurisdiction under the Act to invite the intervention of State or Territory child welfare officers in proceedings affecting the welfare of a child (Clause 41).

In relation to matrimonial property disputes honourable senators may recall that the original Family Law Act proposed that all disputes between a married couple concerning their custody, maintenance and property rights should be within the exclusive jurisdiction of the Act, irrespective of whether those disputes arose before or after divorce. As a result of the 1976 High Court decision in the Russell case, however, the present unsatisfactory situation has come about whereby custody and maintenance disputes can be determined under the Family Law Act at any time during a marriage or after its dissolution, while disputes as to property cannot be commenced under the Act until divorce proceedings have been commenced between the parties, following 12 months separation.

In accordance with the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee the Bill proposes that proceedings with respect to the property of the parties to the marriage may be commenced under the Act at any time, whether before or after divorce, providing the dispute can be said to arise out of the marital relationship (Sub-clause 3 (1)). This amendment should ensure that all married people are entitled to benefit from the principles in the Family Law Act which are generally far more just than under State law, in that they permit a spouse who has contributed to the acquisition of the matrimonial property in an indirect or non-financial but nevertheless significant way to claim a share in the property without having to institute divorce proceedings.

In relation to property proceedings I also draw attention to the fact that the Family Law Amendment Bill as introduced by the previous Government contained an amendment to permit property proceedings to continue after the death of one of the parties to those proceedings, In making an order in such proceedings, however, the court would have been restricted to making those orders which would have been available had the deceased party not died. This Government considers that the court in such circumstances ought to be able to make an order which takes into account the fact of death and the circumstances which exist following the death. The new Bill will achieve this purpose (Clause 31 and 32).

There is one further area in which an expansion of jurisdiction of the Family Court is proposed by the Bill. I refer here to the amendments which will enable the Family Court in the Australian Capital Territory to be invested with as broad a jurisdiction as possible in family law matters. It is my hope, and the ultimate aim of this Government, that the Family Court throughout Australia will one day exercise such a broad jurisdiction.
Procedures and Structure of Family Court

Among the most important and necessary changes recommended by the Joint Select Committee in the procedural area were that courts exercising jurisdiction under the Act should be opened to the public and that the existing total prohibition on the publication of details of proceedings under the Act should be relaxed, provided that the parties to such proceedings were not identified. Although these recommendations did not have the unanimous support of all members of the Joint Select Committee, they were endorsed by the Family Law Council and were accepted by the previous Attorney-General. They are accepted by this Government and are implemented by this Bill (Clauses 46 and 65). It is this Government's view that much of the largely misconceived criticism to which the Family Court has been subject, particularly in recent times, should disappear when the court is open to the public and details of its operation in particular cases can be published. This, it is to be hoped, will enable better understanding of the way the court operates, and will promote an informed and constructive debate on the future development of family law.

I am aware that certain honourable senators are concerned that to permit publication of details of Family Court proceedings will result in unwanted intrusions into the privacy of litigants. I would seek to allay those concerns by explaining that the Bill prohibits any account of proceedings under the Act which identifies a party to those proceedings. There are detailed rules as to what will constitute identification and steeply increased penalties for an infringement of the prohibition (Clause 65).

Another important recommendation of the Joint Select Committee was that there should be a pool of Family Court judges from which Full Courts would be constituted to hear appeals. Certain of these judges would be permanent members of the pool; others would sit on appeals by rotation. The Bill as introduced by the previous Government provided for the creation of an Appeal Division the membership of which was to be fixed. This Government prefers the model suggested by the Joint Select Committee, whereby certain members of the Appeal Division will be permanent members and other members will be appointed for a limited period. The Bill accordingly proposes an Appeal Division comprising up to five permanent members together with an unspecified number of other judges who will hold appointment in the Appeal Division for two years only (Sub-clause 3 (1); Clauses 7, 8, 9 and 10).

One of the most important additional amendments that this Government is proposing in the Bill relates to the allocation of work within the Family Court. At the present time a tremendous amount of judicial time is spent on very routine types of matters, in particular 'pre-trial' or 'duty' work such as the giving of directions regarding pre-trial procedure and the making of interim or consent orders.

It is considered by the Family Court and the Family Law Council that if this routine type of work could be done by officers of the court other than judges, the judges would be able to devote more time to substantial defended matters, thereby achieving a more effective use of judicial time and a reduction in the delays in the hearing of matters before the court.

Fortified by statements made by various members of the High Court in the 1982 case Commonwealth of Australia v. H.C.F. of Australia, the Government has therefore included provisions in the Bill to permit Registrars and Deputy Registrars of the Family Court, as officers who truly form part of the court's organisation, to exercise a greater range of powers in proceedings under the Act but subject always to review by a judge (Clause 66).

I come now to that somewhat controversial amendment that will enable undefended divorce applications to be determined without the necessity for either of the parties or their legal representatives to attend a court hearing (Clause 47). The Government is aware that a similar amendment in the 1981 Bill attracted some criticism from certain groups. Nevertheless the Government is convinced of the value of this amendment as an important development towards streamlining the procedures of the Family Court and reducing costs to litigants. I would mention that there are safeguards, both in the amendment and in the Act itself, against divorce applications being granted in error under the new procedure. If the new procedure is to be used by a party, the other party will be able, by making a prior objection, to ensure a hearing of the divorce application. The court will still have to be satisfied, on the basis of evidence before it, that the marriage has broken down and that there is no reasonable likelihood of cohabitation being resumed. Further, before a divorce decree can become absolute , the court will still be required, except in special circumstances, to declare that it is satisfied that proper arrangements have been made for the welfare of any children of the marriage under 18 years.

Other amendments of a procedural or structural nature that were proposed by the Joint Select Committee and which are included in the new Bill are: Amendments that will permit the judges of the Family Court to make Rules of Court, as do judges of other superior courts (Clause 68); amendments that will enable parties to make joint applications for divorce (Sub-clause 3 (1) and Clause 20); and amendments to expand the duties of a full-time Marshall of the Family Court ( Clause 13). One of the principal duties of a full-time Marshall will be, as recommended by the Joint Select Committee, liaison with the various police forces to ensure the more effective enforcement of Family Court orders.
Changes to Substantive Law
I come now to those amendments in the Bill which affect the principles that are applied by courts and the remedies that are available in proceedings under the Act.

In relation to proceedings concerning children, the new Bill follows its predecessor by including an amendment permitting the Family Court to take into account any wishes of a child, no matter of what age, and to give to such wishes what weight it considers appropriate (Clause 25). This replaces that existing requirements that the court give effect to the wishes of a child of 14 years or over.

The Bill also implements certain Joint Select Committee recommendations in relation to children which were not taken up by the previous Government but which are wholeheartedly endorsed by this Government. In particular, Government departments and other persons or bodies who have information concerning the likely whereabouts of a missing child who is the subject of a custody order may now be required to divulge such information to the court, subject to appropriate safeguards (Clause 25).

The Bill also contains for the first time an express statement of the criteria that the Family Court must take into account in determining guardianship and custody matters. I am aware that the recommendation by the Joint Select Committee for the insertion of such criteria in the Act has not met with universal approval. We are, however, persuaded by the arguments advanced by the Joint Select Committee that such an amendment should assist the more rapid resolution of disputes over children by introducing greater certainty and predictability into the exercise of the Family Court's discretion in this controversial and emotive area (Clause 25).

The Bill provides that there should be no final order in guardianship and custody cases until the parties have attended a conference with a court counsellor. This amendment reflects the philosophy of this Government that every effort must be made to resolve disputes by processes of conciliation and counselling and that recourse to the court and the adversary process must be a last resort (Clause 25).

Another amendment, also recommended by the Joint Select Committee, that will contribute towards the protection and welfare of children is that which will permit the Family Court to attach a power of arrest to an injunction granted for the personal protection of either a child of a marriage or a party to the marriage. This Government believes that the Court should be able to attach a power of arrest order to an injunction not only where violence has already been committed but also where violence has been threatened, and the Bill provides accordingly (Clause 58). I would mention that this further amendment will result in greater consistency between the Family Law Act and the various recent State Acts which deal with domestic violence. The relevant provisions in the Bill have been drafted on the basis that the Commonwealth provisions do not operate to exclude effective State provisions in this area (Clause 58).

Finally in relation to children, the Bill seeks to attribute some meaning to the hitherto undefined terms of 'guardian' or 'guardianship' and 'custody'. The Joint Select Committee recommended that these terms should be defined, and perhaps more importantly that their usage should be consistent with other Commonwealth and State legislation. The Family Law Council's Watson Committee recommended, after a thorough examination, that definitions be inserted into the Act. The Bill accordingly provides that a guardian of a child under the Family Law Act is the person who has the responsibility for the long-term welfare of the child-which according to the Watson Committee should include such matters as 'decisions concerning the (child's) education, changes in place of residence, religion, employment and any health needs other than of a routine or urgent nature'-as well as all the other powers, rights and duties that are vested by law or custom in the guardian of a child. It further provides that a person who has or is granted custody of a child under the Family Law Act has the right to possession of the child and the responsibility for the daily care and control of the child. The Watson Committee intended this responsibility to encompass ' decisions concerning accommodation, attendance at school, clothing, feeding, transportation, behaviour and urgent or routine health needs' (Clause 22).

I am aware that these amendments will involve a departure from the existing practice and usage that has grown up under the Family Law Act, whereby ' guardianship' has more or less fallen into disuse and 'custody' has come to mean virtually the full legal rights in respect of a child. The term 'care and control', though not mentioned in the Act, is currently used to mean possession. Recognising that this course may cause at least some short term confusion, I am nevertheless persuaded by the arguments put forward by the Watson Committee in support of its recommendation. I would add that these amendments will achieve the Joint Select Committee's desire for uniformity in Commonwealth and State legislation.

In relation to the Family Court's powers in property settlement proceedings, the Bill puts beyond doubt that the court has the power to adjourn such proceedings where this is necessary to enable ultimate justice to be done between the parties in cases where the financial circumstances of one of the parties are likely to change in the future (Clause 31). This will be particulary important where one party will in the future became entitled to superannuation benefits and there is at the time of the initial hearing of the application little other property for distribution between the parties. This Bill also proposes an extension of the range of circumstances in which the court may vary or set aside an earlier property settlement order (Clause 32).

The Bill also revises, and relocates in the Family Law Act, the provisions of Part III of the Migration Act relating to offences for the removal from Australia of children in respect of whom custody or like orders have been made or sought. Increased penalties for these offences are provided (Clause 29). The relocation was recommended by the Interdepartmental Committee on Prevention of Removal of Children from Australia by One Parent in 1979. It will more effectively bring the offence provisions to the notice of the public and legal profession alike.

Also relevant to the issue of the wrongful removal of children is the amendment in the Bill which enables regulations to be made to enable Australia to implement the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction (Clause 55). I have high regard for the Convention's approach to the problem of international child abduction as it will ensure the speedy, almost automatic return of abducted children. It will not permit the abductor to make use of the custody jurisdiction of courts in the country of destination, thereby eliminating the advantage that sometimes accrues to an abductor by the passage of time.

The Bill also makes the necessary amendments to enable Australia to accede to the Hague Convention on the Recognition of Divorces and Legal Separations ( Clause 49). These amendments will require Australia to recognize as valid legal separations of married persons effected under overseas law where the persons have the required connection with the relevant overseas country. Certain other amendments to enable accession are necessary, in particular amendments which will result in an Australian court being bound by certain findings of fact in overseas proceedings associated with a marriage, and also to modify the grounds on which recognition of an overseas divorce, decree of nullity of marriage or of legal separation of married persons may be refused in Australia.

In addition the opportunity is taken to insert in the Bill a regulation-making power to enable Australia to implement the Hague Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Decisions Relating to Maintenance Obligations (Clause 55). No decision has as yet been taken on implementation of this Convention, as Government policy is to give priority to the long overdue implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Recovery Abroad of Maintenance, which I believe will provide considerable benefits for the ethnic community in Australia.

As I mentioned at the outset, the Government regards the principle of no-fault divorce as accepted and settled. There is not the remotest prospect, in practical political terms, of a return to fault-based divorce. I hope therefore that debate on this Bill will be directed to the many important reforms it seeks to implement. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

5. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, two significant Bills are before the Senate this evening, namely, the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill and the Taxation (Unpaid Income Tax-Dividends) Bill. I make clear at the outset the Opposition's rejection of these Bills. It was claimed by the Government to be an extension of the recoupment legislation of last year. It in no way could be described in that manner, but we must see it as the first and opening salvo of the Hawke Government in taxation legislation. It states that it will collect something over $500m. If we recall some of the statements of Mr Hawke last year when he was commenting on the ready availability of large sums of money in the Australian community from tax avoidance and evasion, he was talking about something like $15,000m. If we look at this legislation as being the way in which the Government seeks to raise something over $500m, we must ask: What is the form that the next legislation is to take that we can expect from a government that introduces Bills and exposes them as being an extension of the recoupment legislation of last year?

SPEECH.PARA: A promise was given by Mr Hawke that there would be no introduction of capital gains tax by a Hawke Labor Government. I would have to argue that the legislation before us does just that; it introduces a tax on capital gains and taxes wealth. It also applies legislation retrospectively to both those areas of growth. In no way would I describe it as an extension of last year's recoupment legislation. The legislation last year was designed to recoup tax that was due and payable. The then Government was not seeking to create a new tax liability.

The legislation that is before us this evening is retrospective in every sense of the word in its intent and its application. The Bills create a liability which never previously existed. They are not normal, revenue raising Bills. I speak on behalf of all the members of the Opposition when I say that we adopt the same stance to these Bills as we did last year. In fact, many of the provisions that are before us in the legislation this evening reverse amendments that were specificially inserted in the previous Government's Bills last year, or they propose changes which were specifically raised by the Labor Opposition last year and rejected by us when we were in government.

I repeat that the tax introduced under this legislation is a new tax. As I assert that without equivocation I think it is timely to query the title of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill that is before us. I think we need to ask: To what unpaid income tax is the amending Bill directed? No unpaid income tax is assessed against shareholders independent of the principal Act. That part of the name of the Bill 'Unpaid Company Tax' gives the impression that something is unpaid, whereas the Bill introduces and imposes a new tax.

If the shares had not been sold there would not have been the type of tax burden to which the amending Bill is directed. Firstly, if the company were to continue to operate, dividends from current year profits alone after retention would have been declared which would not have involved accumulated profits from previous years which had already borne tax, nor would it have involved capital profits not subject to tax in the hands of the company. Secondly, if the operations of the company were to be discontinued it would have been put into liquidation. Distributions by the liquidator, to the extent that they represented capital profits, would not have been regarded as dividends in the shareholder's hands. Thirdly, it would have to be said that no one would have taken the step, upon which the amending Act appears to be based, of converting the company's assets to cash and then declaring a dividend from both revenue and capital reserves.

This legislation proposes to tax both the accumulated profits and the capital reserve of the company. The accumulated profits previously would have borne company tax at the rate of 46c in the dollar and undistributed profits would have borne tax at the rate that was specified under the Act at the time. On top of that, under this Bill, there will be a further tax of 60c in the dollar.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not necessarily.

— Tax will have to be paid at a rate of up to 60c in the dollar. It is a capital gains tax or, more accurately, I think it is a wealth tax. The legislation is such that it reaches far back into the company' s history, into the operations of the company. It imputes and deems certain circumstances that are described throughout the legislation that did not happen. It seeks then to tax the result of those things which the Bill deems to have occurred. It exemplifies another broken promise, that there would be no capital gains tax. I think that was a special and unequivocal promise of the Government. It was a policy promise, a promise of the now Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). This legislation not only breaks that promise but also breaks with it restrospective effect.

SPEECH.PARA: If the amendments to the definitions of the promoter's recoupment tax and the vendor's recoupment tax and the newly defined dividend recoupment tax are meant to enable the Commissioner of Taxation to recover additional tax assessed against the company under section 226 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the question must arise: Why should a vendor of shares be penalised three times for the company's failure? For example, if it is proposed that a vendor-shareholder pay the additional tax as part of his recoupment tax, he is penalised once. The amending Bill proposes to assess the vendor-shareholder, to tax upon a dividend amount under clause 12 determined by the distributable amount-clause 8, page 6- which is to be determined after deduction of the company tax liability, as shown by clause 8 (3), page 7. But the amount of the company tax liability does not include additional tax under section 226 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, as shown by clause 8, page 7, paragraph 4 (c) of this Bill. Thus the shareholder is penalised a second time by his dividend amount not being reduced by the amount of the additional tax. By the Government seeking to impose the tax as part of the vendor-shareholer's dividend recoupment tax, the vendor-shareholder is penalised a third time in respect of the same additional tax of the company. No doubt if this is not the intent of the Government a series of very complex amendments could be raised to deal with what seems to be an absurdity, but that is what is provided in the Bill that is before us and, as I am advised, that is the effect of the Bill that is before us.

Considering the consequences of the Bill, it can be described only as punitive. Its intent is enshrined in a dogmatic philosophy which is intolerant of the holding or building of capital. We have seen that sort of dogmatic philosophy reflected in the superannuation debacle which is presently before the Australian community. We see it in the speeches and comments of members of the Government and members of the Australian Labor Party. The legislation before us exemplifies the enshrining of a dogmatic philosophy which is intolerant of the holding or building of capital.

I think it was said at the time that some of these decisions were taken that the Government would make some tough economic decisions. This legislation before us could in no way be regarded as tough economic decisions because they are punitive decisions. They are destructive decisions. They are destructive of companies; they are destructive of employment opportunities. They also ignore a policy of the present Government with regard to the retention of profits in a business, as is provided for under Division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Because they ignore that retention of profits properly in a business for the building of capital, the building of resources within the business, they sit very uneasily with another Government policy promise-to move to 100 per cent retention of profits in the business to assist small businesses to accumulate their capital, to employ their capital, to provide employment and to assist in the economic growth of Australia. This is another broken promise applied retrospectively over the years of the accumulation of the capital of the company .

In recent days in Canberra I am sure that every senator has had representations from numbers of concerned people in regard to the application of this legislation to their own businesses. We have had examples galore given to us- perhaps some of my colleagues will wish to express those examples in more detail -of the effect of the legislation on the operations of companies. We have had many expressions from prominent and talented members of the legal and accounting professions who have described to us the effect of this legislation. The new tax is imposed on companies that have borne tax according to the law at the time. The legislation reaches back in some cases for 50 years or more. These are companies that have borne the tax according to the law that applied to them. For this reason, the retrospectivity of this legislation is absolutely abhorrent.

The Law Council of Australia has provided some very thoughtful examination of the Bills before us. The Taxation Committee of the Law Council of Australia and many of the State divisions, together with other independent council and tax accountants, have provided a great deal of information. I am sure many honourable senators are in possession of the sort of information that has been provided. When the Taxation Committee of the Law Council of Australia describes the Bill as one that is designed to impose retrospectively a liability for taxation on former shareholders of companies, and when it expresses its view that it opposes that retrospectivity, we should look at the Bills to see exactly what their effect is and the retrospective nature of that effect.

The legislation eliminates the right of former shareholders pursuant to section 3 (12) of the 1982 Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act. That is a matter that concerns the Taxation Committee of the Law Council. The proposal to eliminate the provisions of paragraph (h) of sections 5 (1) and 5 (2) is an attempt to deem certain arrangements which did not have the effect of making it impossible for the company to pay any unpaid tax to be arrangements which did have that effect. To deem something to have occurred that did not have the effect of making the company unable to pay its tax seems to be a very inappropriate form of legislation for a government to impose. The Law Council is particularly concerned about the proposals in paragraphs 5A, 6A, 6C and 6E. It finds them entirely objectionable. It draws attention to the 1977 High Court decision in the Slutzkin case. It is well accepted by everybody that the form of this legislation certainly overturns the judgment in that case and the application of the law.

Former shareholders of companies who disposed of their shares have always had the expectation that no part of the receipts on the sale of their shares would be deemed to be a distribution of the undistributed profits of the company. That is nothing new. That is an expectation that has always been accepted and understood. Moreover, the effect of the Bill will be to deem accumulated capital profits of companies to be dividends. As we have heard around the Parliament in the last day or two, that is something that concerns not only people who have their businesses at risk but also those of use who are parliamentary representatives. When I say that I understand that I speak not only for this side of the chamber but also for members of the Government's party who are concerned about the effect of accumulated capital profits under this legislation .

The present proposal seeks to impose a further liability on former shareholders of companies. To deem accumulated capital profits to be dividends, as is done in this legislation, is of very great concern and will have enormous consequences. It is one thing to talk of collecting retrospectively tax which was due but upaid. It is entirely another thing to collect retrospectively an entirely new tax. That is what is being done in this case.

I said earlier in my remarks this evening that we are looking at a capital gains tax. It has also been put to me that it is nothing less than a wealth tax. It goes beyond a capital gains tax because shareholders are to be taxed on a notional but unreal accretion in the value of their shares when they have neither sold them nor taken any part, especially in the case of shareholders in public companies, in the sale of shares in subsidiary companies and their ultimate disappearance. No justification exists for deeming profits to be distributed and to be taxable in shareholders hands when they are either of a capital nature or are tax-paid profits of previous years. It is quite inconceivable to me that any company would distribute these as taxable dividends .

A number of sections have been expressed as being of great concern. Section 6 ( 2) provides that if there are any sales of shares in a vendor company the liability for dividend recoupment tax can be shifted from the company to the shareholders if the Commissioner thinks it would be unreasonable to assess the company. That would require some interpretation and some description. Section 21 has been restored to the Bill to allow time for payment, but it does not apply unless all shareholders wish for time to pay. This, of course, affects shareholders who may wish to have their right to pay by instalments or whatever other arrangement they may wish to make. So an amendment introduced by the Government after the legislation was brought down is not something that necessarily will help all people, but that is how the Bill stands at present.

What concerned me when looking at the debate in the House of Representatives was that the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, made a purely political response to what is a most significant piece of legislation. No attempt was made in the summing up of that debate to explain the legislation and there was no debate in the Committee of the Whole. No opportunity was taken to explain, to expand or to respond on the points that had been raised by the honourable members who had spoken in the debate. In fact one rather chilling thing that was said by the Minister was that retrospectivity is a most effective weapon. One must ask: 'A most effective weapon against what?' Retrospectivity in legislation is a most effective weapon if one wants to change the rules. It is a most effective weapon if certainty in the rule of law and in business is to be destroyed. It is a most effective weapon if one wants to destroy capital accretion. It is a very destructive way in which to provide legislation that has to be accepted through the Parliament. It has to be assumed that we have a very destructive Government if retrospectivity is to be the most effective weapon as a measure of its legislative program. Retrospectivity that destroys the certainty that people need to have to uphold the rule of law and to be able to determine their affairs is, I think, a reprehensible way in which a government can approach its legislation. When it is as far reaching as this income tax legislation it is something of very great concern.

It may well be asked why there is such concern by business about the effect of the legislation. We cannot look at anything that affects business at present without looking at the conditions in our economy, the current recession and the difficulties. Because of the current recession, the real net worth of business is less than existing recoupment tax plus 60 per cent of real reserves, let alone plus 60 per cent of book entry reserves. That is why concern is being expressed all round the business community that this legislation will result in a financial wipe-out and in the destruction of business and employment. We are looking at what a business is able to do in the present circumstances of economic difficulty. While it is paying its way with the ever-increasing wage demands and other demands that are made upon it we are asking it to pay a tax of 60 per cent on its accumulated reserves and profits on which it has already paid tax. It seems to me that this legislation could not find support in the Australian Parliament because it would not find support amongst the Australian people. There are a number of speakers who will wish to make points on the legislation and to describe their reaction to it, or their party's reaction to it, but I wish to state on behalf of the Opposition that we are totally opposed to it. We are aware of the serious consequences which will be introduced into the business community through this legislation. The application retrospectively of a tax of this nature is something that should not find support in the Australian Senate.
