SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we debate these two Bills, the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 and the Taxation (Unpaid Income Tax-Dividends) Bill 1983, I want to point out that we are breaking new ground. This legislation imposes entirely new taxes. It is imposing a capital gains tax which is retrospective, discriminatory and blatantly unfair in a number of areas. Under this legislation the realisation of some property which could been held for generations, passed on from father to son-property which could have been held for over 100 years-is now to be regarded as profit if that transaction occurred between 1972 and the date of the introduction of the new Part IVA of the income tax legislation. The Government has introduced perhaps the most discriminatory form of capital gains tax ever placed before any parliament anywhere in the world. That shows the extent of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that the Government, in framing this legislation rather hastily, has failed to take into account all the consequences that will flow from it. As little as $101 tax on current year's profit could render perhaps millions of dollars worth of capital gains being subject to income tax under this legislation. Admittedly, that $101 would have to flow to the principal shareholder, but that is the trigger mechanism. How is this legislation going to work? It is unreal because traditionally, in this country, we have not had a capital gains tax as such apart from short term capital gains as dealt with in section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Some of this property could have been held for years or generations. I am referring to land, buildings and good will-all these sorts of things. If such property has been liquidated in an ordinary liquidation, under section 47 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the following will apply:

Distributions to shareholders of a company by a liquidator in the course of winding-up the company, to the extent to which they represent income derived by the company (whether before or during liquidation) other than income which had been properly applied to replace a loss of paid-up capital, shall, for the purposes of this Act, be deemed to be dividends paid to the shareholders by the company out of profits derived by it.

In the current situation it is being deemed, by hypothesis, that in effect a liquidator would make an unreal decision before liquidation and pay a dividend, effectively converting a capital gain to revenue. That is just not on. I do not think a liquidator would have done it at any time within the history of this Federation. There is no point in defining capital gains as income. This is exactly what this legislation does. It deems capital profits to be income. I hope that some sense will prevail because otherwise the damage to the community will be widespread. I hope that the Government will at least consider introducing an amendment.

We know the thrust of the Bill. The rhetoric is good-try to ensure that everyone pays their just and equitable share of income tax catch-up with the tax avoiders. But the tax avoidance industry, as everybody knows now, has been dead for about 12 months. What are we doing? We are using some pretty artificial devices, in some cases to catch some very innocent and some very old people. This legislation, I venture to say, will put some of the most respected and the most thrifty members of society into bankruptcy, through no fault of their own. They did not enter into an artificial, blatant, contrived tax avoidance scheme. What did they do? They built up their business through prudent management over the years, some of them over generations, and for one reason or another-because they reached retirement or because a larger company, through an arm's length transaction, purchased that business-they disposed of that business. Such a company is interested in the land, the buildings, the plant, the trademarks and all those sorts of things. The companies that acquire such land and buildings are not interested in taking over the capital structures of the business itself; they just want the plant, the assets, the land and the buildings.

These people exchange their shares for shares in a new company or for cash. It is as simple as that. After about a year the business is sold and carried on by the new operators at arm's length and they are left with a shell of a company which probably represents cash, shares or something like that, appropriated profits and the capital. The usual procedure is to appoint a liquidator. The liquidator, in liquidating that company, pays out the paid-up capital-a return on capital which is not assessable. It will not be assessable under this legislation. Also in the company's balance sheet are some capital reserves. What sort of capital reserves are we looking at? There would be profits on the sale of land and buildings. If that business has been held for generations the land and buildings might be listed in the books for a nominal figure and, particularly in a city, those profits could be quite substantial. Millions of dollars of capital profits could be at risk. This land and these buildings will suddenly be caught. In a normal liquidation under section 47 of the Act they would be disposed of tax free. This is the anomaly. The people have a choice of putting the company into the hands of a liquidator or selling it off. Another operator could pick up that shell and form a new company. It is as simple as that. The choice is there.

Let us consider those people who chose to sell off the company, who provided their tax returns based on the current year's profits, did the right thing and then suddenly went into liquidation; then somewhere along the line, unbeknown to them, the wrong thing was done. It is a bit like me selling my house and the new purchaser, unbeknown to me, in a year or two converting it to a brothel. Why should I have a stigma attached to me by the actions of a person down the line? Surely that is inequitable. Yet this legislation would allow such a transaction to be traced back and I would become personally responsibile for somebody else's action down the line.

Why should not the Commissioner of Taxation attack the liquidators-those people who perpetrated these heinous crimes and created the artificiality? What are we doing by this legislation? We are penalising the innocent people, people who, I venture to say, have done absolutely nothing wrong at all. One might say that they have the cash and are in a position to pay. What pathetic argument. I might have received cash from the sale of my house, but surely I would not be liable for the transgressions and sins of those people who bought that house and used it for ill-famed purposes. I think that analogy is pretty appropriate. Let me return to the actions of the liquidator. If he had liquidated the company, the profits on the land and buildings, when distributed, would have been exempt from tax. This legislation seeks to impose a tax on those profits.

What else is there? Goodwill could be included. At present it is non-taxable. I take as an example a fellow who goes into business. Because of his enterprise, the character of the business, its position and what he has put into it the business could be worth much more than he paid for it. Under this legislation that person would be taxed on those gains. For the first time there is to be a new tax on capital. Goodwill, which is a bona fide asset revaluation reserve, will be taxable for the first time. How dreadful. A wide range of items is involved. Reserves on the issue of convertible notes, if disributed by a liquidator, also were tax free. For generations this has been covered by section 47. Dividends which prior to 1947 had been subject to Division 7, section 109 taxes, if distributed by a liquidator, again were exempt, tax free. We are bringing those dividends within the net of this legislation. I venture to say that if we had any conscience we would be prepared-

TALK.START.PARA: —Cheats should not prosper.

—This has nothing to do with cheats. The honourable senator is losing the main thrust of what I am trying to say. I am talking about the reputable people. Let us concentrate on them. The Government is trying to bring the blackguards, the tax avoiders and all those other people on a parity with the people who tried to do the right thing. Let us try to have some moral courage to separate those who have done the right thing from those who are parasites on society. I will say more about those other people later. But let us have some moral courage. If we do not have the gumption to defeat this Bill, if we are not prepared to put through the right sorts of amendments to give this legislation a little respectability, the only thing we can do, because time is running out, is to put the matter before a committee so that we can receive some informed advice which will give us some moral fortitude to separate the wheat from the chaff.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is rather unfortunate and a reflection on this Parliament that we are prepared to pass in this present form legislation that I believe is almost unparalleled anywhere in the world. The legislation will tax profits of a capital nature-not of a revenue nature-that have been accumulated over generations, profits which, had they been put into the hands of a liquidator, would not have attracted tax. Therefore, I believe, as a minimum, that an amendment to this legislation must be accepted but I appeal to honourable senators in the first instance to defeat the legislation outright. I hope that Senator Haines will be able to muster the numbers to be able to defeat this legislation. The Government should introduce later appropriate legislation which is fair and which has been considered over time. But it should not force through legislation in the dying hours of the Parliament which we will regret. It is unfortunate. An amendment should be made to provide that the capital profits reserves of certain classes of companies be exempt from the operation of amendments to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 1982. Those companies should include those which, at the date on or before which the shares were sold, had accumulated bona fide capital profits-naturally, this would be left to the discretion of the Commissioner, because we know, in practice, what are bona fide capital profits, as he does-and made provision for all company primary taxes on their taxable profits to the date of sale and paid over the amount of the liability to the purchaser of those shares.

We must insist upon that amendment as an absolute minimum, if this legislation is to be passed. Apart from that, there is a host of other items which are completely foreign to us. Let us not depart from this place until we have defeated the legislation, or at least passed that amendment. It will be a shame on this Parliament, and on us as senators, to overlook such a travesty of justice to ordinary individuals. Many people may ask: What is the difference between the legislation that we are debating tonight and the legislation that was passed last year, which is commonly referred to as recoupment legislation? That is a fair question. The recoupment legislation that was passed by the Liberal-National Party Government last year sought to tax those current year profits that had not been taxed; in other words, there was a tax liability in respect of profits for those years in which, because of some dodgers using artificial means, it was not met, because the company had effectively been put to the bottom of the harbour-what is commonly referred to as a bottom-of-the- harbour scheme. So a tax liability was created which had not been met. By an artificial, contrived mechanism, company tax was not paid.

The legislation went further. It stated that the undistributed profits that would apply to that particular profit should also bear tax at the appropriate rate. The present legislation seeks to take the next step down the line and to attack the profits that have been accumulated over a long period and also the capital reserves or capital profits. Those profits which have been accumulated over time are to be taxed rather than those that apply to a particular period. This is unfortunate because it is very discriminatory. This situation is known as a Slutzkin type case. The High Court, in the Slutzkin case, held that where a person traded in a company that did not have current year profits-in other words , a company which had accumulated profits-those profits were deemed to be of a capital nature. So what does this legislation do? It cuts across an established High Court decision. What is the value of having an independent High Court if taxes are to be imposed retrospectively? There is no point. How will accountants and lawyers advise clients in the future? There will be absolutely no certainty in anything from now on. Advice may be given along a particular line, but legislation may be passed not to operate as from the day of its announcement, as under Liberal Party policy, and not to apply from a particular future date, but to operate retrospectively not only back to 1972 but for a whole host of years prior to that time. As I say, these profits might have been accumulated over a number of years. A decision of the High Court, the highest court of the land, in respect of taxation matters lays down a precedent. But this legislation will retrospectively override that and render it null and void. What sort of government will people think we have when it does those sorts of things?

There are two different types of schemes. The Slutzkin scheme involves purely unappropriated profits, with no current year taxes. Under a wet Slutzkin scheme as little as $101 might accrue to one individual taxpayer, and now suddenly all profits are to be subject to tax. Is that not unfair? Such profits might not be derived from trading during the year but from bank interest which has accumulated. In such cases there has been no attempt to deceive or to contrive and there is nothing artificial. On the one hand, once a certain stage is reached the whole amount for capital gains and accumulated profits is to be subject to tax. On the other hand, a dry Slutzkin scheme with no current year profits is completely exempt. One company with $1m may have no current year profits; another company may have $1m in accumulated profits. One is up for a hell of a lot of tax, which will bankrupt all the proprietors, and the other escape tax free. Is that not discriminatory? Have we ever in the past seen before Parliament anything so retrograde or anything which will discriminate to quite that extent? Where is the fairness to people? There is absolutely no fairness in that at all.

The Government has a number of choices. It tells us that it has to take some fairly tough measures in order to get the Budget deficit down. What will it do? What is the effect of this legislation on those who have acted honourably as distinct from those that have perhaps used what is known as a round robin scheme ? I do not have much time for the round robin scheme. We must separate the two types of case. The Government, has failed to separate the two types of case- those who are honourable and just, and those who are scoundrels. That is the wicked part of this legislation. It fails to distinguish between the honest members of the community and the dishonest ones. Is that not a dreadful thing? Is it not a reflection upon this Parliament, let alone on the present Government ?

The Government has a choice. It says that it has to finance the deficit. We recognise that to do that it will impose some fairly horrific taxes and fairly horrific penalties for those who get caught. Unfortunately, what will happen to the employees of a lot of these businesses? As we know, some of these people have been using these taxation arrangements-some legitimately and some not. I recognise that and I drew the distinction earlier. What will happen is that the employees will lose their jobs because to find the money to pay this tax will more than bankrupt some people. If we look at the rates of tax we see that they are fairly horrific.

I would venture to say that if we were trying to be fair and reasonable we would not be imposing taxes, through the provisions in this Bill, ranging from a minimum of 60c of the deemed dividend or hypothetical dividend. One cannot call it a dividend because it is hypothetical; it is assumed. People will be taxed at rates of up to 69.62 per cent-nearly 70c in the dollar. We are told that the legislation of last year in relation to the recoupment tax almost put people on the verge of going out of business. Some may not have gone out of business but this legislation will decimate them. What about all those people-people in the old companies that have been operating for generations? These people are probably in their twilight years. They might have had a trip around the world. They will suddenly find that they will be paying tax at the rate of nearly 70c in the dollar. How much will they have left? I pity them.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are looking after the tax avoiders.

—I am not looking after the tax avoiders. The honourable senator knows very well that I am trying to separate the two classes. That is the weakness in this legislation. The Government has not had the moral fortitude to separate the wheat from the chaff, the honest people from those who have been dishonest and put artificial schemes into play. If this Parliament had any moral fortitude would it not bring back the rate to the undistributed rate of 50c in the dollar? That is what we would do. We would deem it to be undistributed. We would apply that rate which applies in relation to private companies-50c in the dollar. Alternatively, would not the Government use the middle rate of income tax of 46c in the dollar? No, the Government chooses these penalty rates-the maximum rates that apply in the circumstances-assuming that all the people who pay this tax are top poppies. Everybody in this place assumes that people who own a share in a company must be virtually millionaires and that they must pay tax at the maximum rate. That is just not on. I think this is reflected in the fact that the other day the Government passed legislation which effectively wiped out exemptions to individuals for dividends for which the Liberal Government provided and which would have encouraged small investors to invest sums under $1,000. The present Government assumes that everybody is a tall poppy -a millionaire-who pays tax at the marginal rate. If the Government had any moral fortitude and wanted to attract this sort of tax it would apply tax at the reasonable rate. If the Government wanted to apply tax at a reasonable rate it would go back to using the undistributed profits rate of tax.
—Are you going to vote for it then?
—My conscience would not let me vote for this legislation in its present form.
—No, if we bring it back. Then are you going to vote for it?

—Bringing it back is the only ray of hope we have heard tonight. Let us hope that the honourable senator can get around his colleagues and bring about some sort of method to defer this legislation. The best thing we can do is to pack up the books now and have another look at this legislation. If the Government is prepared to put this legislation before a committee, I am prepared to vote for that. I think we either have to defeat it or look at it in a more reasonable light. That is the challenge. I leave the decision to the Labor Party . I say to Senator Ray from the Labor Party that I am encouraged by the fact that he put forward that idea. That is the only ray of hope I have heard in all this dreadful debate. We will tend to regret this legislation. I am talking about not only the members of the Labor Party who have been responsible for this legislation but also we as politicians. It may be argued that we did not fight hard enough to stop the legislation, despite what we are trying to do tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has a choice. It can try to collect the maximum amount of tax possible by squeezing every bit it can, no matter whether people are rich or poor, no matter whether they are tax avoiders or honest operators. But by squeezing taxpayers, what will it do to the economy? We all know that at present the economy is pretty vulnerable. There are a lot of people whose businesses are tottering on the edge. The Government will put the employees-again, the innocent fellows-out on the street. What opportunities will they have? The Government is attacking capital accretions. It is an unfortunate tax.

My time has nearly run out and I am not half way through dealing with this blessed matter. We are in trouble. We will regret this move. I appeal to the honourable senators on the Government side. I hope what will happen has pricked their consciences and that the Government will bring in an amendment. That is the minimum it can do because it will live to regret this legislation. It is a most retrospective, heinous tax. It is a new tax. It is an unfortunate one and it will have tremendous repercussions across the community that I think we will live to regret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President-
—I take a point of order. I would like to move for an extension of time for Senator Watson. I wonder whether that is possible.
—Senator Tate has received the call .

—I am not surprised that Senator Walters has tried to stop my speaking in my defence of this important legislation-the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill and the Taxation (Unpaid Income Tax- Dividends) Bill-which is a part of the fulfilment of the Government's election mandate. There is no doubt that we were elected on the basis that we would take the most robust and concerted action to remove from our midst the deleterious impact on our federal revenues of the stripping of companies which took place in a blatant and contrived way, and continually to the great shame of the previous Liberal-National Party Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of what we are doing tonight-this is what makes so much of what we have heard from the other side hypocrisy and humbug-is an extension of what was introduced into this chamber under great public and political pressure by the now Opposition late last year. We are not afraid-as I have said, we have a mandate-to take the most robust continuing action in relation to the effect of years of contrived and blatant tax avoidance which was, it is not too much to say, connived at, aided and abetted by the previous Government. This occurred until, as I say, public opinion became so overwhelming that it had to make some move in legislative form late last year.

One well remembers the continuing arguments put by the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats in this chamber in regard to the failure of the previous Government to provide either the Commissioner of Taxation or the Crown Solicitor with the sinews of war to fight the battle which needed to be fought on behalf of ordinary, decent tax paying Australians. The fact is that the years of neglect, connivance and aiding and abetting by honourable members opposite led to the situation in which the ordinary wage earner, the pay-as-you-earn tax payer, had to pay higher rates of tax than would otherwise have been the case. This was because the tax avoiders in the community were using contrived schemes to avoid paying into the federal revenues that which was justly required or expected of them. Of course, the PAYE taxpayer, the ordinary wage and salary earner, could not engage in the brilliant, contrived schemes dreamed up by the best brains in the legal and accounting world. Those PAYE taxpayers could not avoid paying higher rates of tax to fill the coffers in order to fulfil the programs of the elected government of the day.

Let us not forget that this legislation is about trying to make amends, about trying to set right the situation which prevailed for so many years in which people in Australia were prepared to take the benefits of living in a free, democratic and wealth-producing society but were not prepared to make a contribution to the Federal Treasury which sustained that society in which they lived so well. As to the retrospective elements of this legislation, there is no doubt that they give cause for some misgivings. It would be remiss of anyone considering this legislation not to advert to that fact. The Senate has long experience now, going back over 50 years, of the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee, which has always brought to the attention of the chamber those instances of delegated law making at the Commonwealth level involving some element of retrospectivity, and which has generally struck them down.

Retrospectivity is not common in our legal and parliamentary tradition. Having said that and having, therefore, been properly cautioned, it is important to realise that it has always been recognised that there is a need to make a distinction in relation to taxation law. I do not take the retrospective aspect of this legislation lightly; I hope I have made that clear. But I find some reassurance in the words of Lord Greene, who was the custodian of the common law tradition in England, the Master of the Rolls, in the 1940s. In a 1941 Court of Appeal decision Lord Greene spoke for himself and for Lord Justices Clauson and du Parcq in a taxation case. I repeat: This is the Court of Appeal in the United Kingdom, the preserver and exponent of our common law tradition. He said:

The fact that the Section has to some extent a retrospective effect again appears to us of no importance when it is realised that the legislation is a move in a long and fiercely-contested battle with individuals who well understand the rigour of the contest.

Surely that is the case in this contest going on between the legislature and those involved in various taxation avoidance schemes. The legal tradition to which we are heir realised and recognised in that statement that retrospective taxation law may be permitted, though I agree that it has to be kept to as narrow a compass as can be justified. Again I am heartened by the fact that on 17 August last year the Australian Financial Review, not the most radical journal known to Australian social and political life, in relation to the legislation which was brought into the chamber by the now Opposition and which this legislation seeks to extend, had this to say:

. . . non-retrospectivity of the tax law is by no stretch of the imagination an absolute moralor political value. . . . Clearly, retrospectivity is more a serious issue with respect to criminal law than with respect to income tax law.

That is exactly the tradition to which we are heirs and which I hope this chamber would always recognise. That distinction has to be maintained, and indeed there are no retrospective criminal penalties involved in the legislation before the chamber tonight. The writer of the Australian Financial Review editorial concluded:

In the case of the bottom of the harbour schemes the abuse of the tax system and the injustice is so gross that justice and fairness are on the side of retrospectivity. But the opponents of retrospectivity rightly warn of the dangers of taking it lightly. It should almost never be done.

So we do have cause for concern, some cause for caution, and some cause for misgivings, but I believe that retrospective aspect of this legislation can be justified. As I said, this legislation is designed to recover from vendor- shareholders and other former owners of companies stripped in schemes of pre-tax profit stripping the tax that those companies did not pay. The Bill extends the scope of that 1982 legislation so as to recover from the former owners of companies stripped of pre-tax profits also the personal income tax which they avoided through those schemes. I do not intend to dwell on the technicalities in this particular legislation. I believe that others are more able, in the Committee stage of the debate, to engage in a more particular dissection of the clauses, which is properly a function of this chamber. I should make it clear that, as I understand it, the Government, since introducing the Bill into the House of Representatives, has made two important concessions, largely in negotiations with Senator Jack Evans of the Australian Democrats, which should allay many of the concerns and some of the misgivings which people have.

In relation to the time within which people will have to pay the tax liability which is imposed on them by this legislation, it had been proposed to abolish the facility for penalty free instalment arrangements, for payment of unpaid company tax which is normally provided. Undoubtedly that would have created hardship. I think it is a good thing that the Government has recognised that there ought to be provision for the payment by instalments of the taxation liability which is assessed under this legislation. Thus, as I understand it now , former owners who do not seek to exercise rights of objection against the target company's assessment as a result of which company tax is payable, can now enter into an arrangement with the Commissioner of Taxation to pay, free of additional tax for late payment, all the company tax payable and to do so by instalments over a period of 12 months or such longer period as the Commissioner allows. I take it that that is a very sensible and wise provision which recognises that people will not have immediately to hand the sort of money which they may be required to make available under this legislation.

Of course, it may be that there are further cases where genuine hardship, devasting effects and consequences and impacts of a kind which would destroy a person's financial well-being and that of his or her family may occur if this legislation is pushed to the extreme limit in particular instances. In relation to that aspect, the Government has said that section 265 of the Income Tax Assessment Act will apply. As honourable senators know, this section of the Act can operate to release a person from liability where it is demonstrated to an absolutely independent arbiter that hardship will occur if the tax liability is pressed to its absolute conclusion. The recognition of that point is extremely important. The fact is that that discretion is exercised by the taxation relief board and whilst it is true that it is an absolute discretion and that, therefore, one cannot say with absolute confidence in relation to any particular case what the outcome might be on an appeal to it, the fact that it is an absolute discretion enables that board to take into account all the relevant circumstances and, without any binding by some previous decision or way of viewing the matter, it can come to a conclusion which is favourable to the taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously have never had any dealings with the Commissioner .

—I think Senator Messner is saying that he has never seen it actually occur in his professional practice. I understand it to be the case that the board of taxation relief does not actually publicise its decisions. If that is the case, it is not surprising that Senator Messner is unable to point to a series of precedents in this field. As I say, the Government has made it very clear-I am relieved, to be quite frank, that it is the case-that in cases of hardship demonstrated to this independent, impartial taxation relief board, the board will exercise a discretion in favour of the taxpayer and not cause that absolute hardship. I have had many telegrams and representations from people who make the claim and the plea that, if the legislation as presently drafted goes through, they will face bankruptcy and penury. But I say that in that situation there is every reason to believe that an approach to the taxation relief board will find a response. I have made the point that most of the pleas have been directed to us in relation to the Bill as it is presently drafted. The fact is that there are still some matters within the Bill which give some legitimate cause for concern. I refer in particular to the inclusion of capital profits with revenue profits in regard to the amount of undistributed company profits covered under the Bill. Perhaps the Government should give that section further careful consideration.
—Did you read Mr Dawkins's Press statement of tonight?

—I have not had an opportunity to do so. I believe that there is legitimate cause for concern in relation to that portion of the Bill which deals with undistributed profits. Having said that, I repeat that the Bill is but part of, and an extension of, the legislation in respect of retrospective taxation which received the support of this chamber late last year. No bluster, no hypocrisy from the other side, can deny that fact.

SPEECH.PARA: Insofar as the passage of this legislation will enable the Government to gather several hundreds of millions of dollars of revenue that it had a legitimate right to expect to gather, had the previous Government taken more vigorous and robust action in relation to tax avoidance schemes. It will be able to provide the sort of tax relief that is needed by the ordinary Australian taxpayer, the honest taxpayer, the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer, who cannot avoid tax by engaging the best legal and accounting brains in the country and perverting them to his or her own selfish ends. It will relieve the ordinary PAYE taxpayer of the need to carry the burden of paying more of his or her income to the Federal Treasury in order to provide the kind of society that we wish to build. Surely that society ought to be built on the basis of everyone making a fair contribution to the Federal revenue.

I also say, and admit, that it ought to be a society in which retrospective legislation is extremely uncommon. I hope that this taxation measure provides one of the last instances of it, but it may be that further instances will be necessary as we clean up the effects of the neglect by the previous Administration in this field. It was an administration, I repeat, which failed to provide the sinews of war, which continued to neglect to give the Commissioner of Taxation the sort of legislative and administrative support that he required. Let us not forget that he made plea after plea that officers be appointed to his Office to strengthen his investigation section in order to carry through investigations as a prelude to recovery. We all know the saga of the administration of the Crown Solicitor's Division where, once again, inadequately trained staff were assigned to taxtion prosecutions in such a way as to lead the tax avoidance industry to believe that it could carry on regardless of the law.

It will be found that this measure, when properly understood by the Australian general public, will be seen as part of the Government's fulfilment of the mandate given to it on 5 March to create a better society. I refer to a society being marked by the distortion of tax which, rather than one in which, as Professor Mathews said in a famous address to the Australian National University , taxation payments by the rich were becoming discretionary-will fulfil our mandate to create a situation in which all Australians who are able to do so will pay a level of taxation which is fair and just and which is limited to the sum required to provide the range of government services and assistance which makes us a civilised, fair and decent society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose this package of Bills which the Government would have us believe just merely strengthens and extends the Bills that the Fraser Government enacted last year to deal with bottom-of- the-harbour tax evaders.
—I hope you declare your interest. Declare your interest.
—I have been asked to declare my interest. My interest is nil. Let us take the point that there is a question--
—What is your occupation? Declare your interest.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask you please to refer Senator Grimes, the Minister for Social Security, to my earlier answer. It is quite clear that I have no interest in this matter whatsoever. There is a difference between this legislation and the law enacted by this Parliament in September-October last year to deal with bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Clearly this legislation introduces a new tax. It imposes a new liability of taxation upon items of a company's income. Those items are to be interpreted, under this law, in a punitive, vindictive, vengeful and, indeed, confiscatory manner. That is the point of this legislation. It is certainly nothing else but. I put it to the Senate that that is an entirely consistent attitude for a person on this side of the Senate to take in the light of his support for the legislation that was passed six months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is absolutely clear because, whereas the tax that we spoke of in the legislation passed last year was a recoupment tax, this is a new tax. It is based on a new set of principles in relation to undistributed profits and capital gains. I will return to that very soon. But I make the point that in the cases about which we are speaking there has never been, as there was in the terms of the legislation brought down last year, illegal evasion. We are talking about consequences arising from avoidance arrangements.

Last year the Government set out to recoup to the Department of the Treasury tax that was due or payable but had been evaded by an illegal act. There was no creation of any new liability. The then Government redeemed an existing tax liability from those who had benefited financially from illegal evasion. I think we need only one very clear example to make that matter absolutely clear even in the minds of Government senators. The former Government established an inquiry under Mr John von Doussa Q.C. to examine the affairs of Mr Horgan. He brought down, as a result of that inquiry, an absolutely clean bill of health for Mr Horgan.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must be joking. Come on, declare your interest. What did you do before you came here?

—That is the kind of attitude that exists on the Government side of the chamber. Government senators are not prepared to take account of facts given as a result of an inquiry undertaken by a person learned in law. He knew what he was doing. He examined very closely the affairs of Mr Horgan and proved that he had a clean bill of health. Mr Horgan is the kind of person who will now be subjected to a confiscatory tax under this legislation. Somebody who has been cleared by an official inquiry will be the subject of this kind of legislation. That is what this law is about. It is absolutely beyond comprehension that even this Government would contemplate bringing this kind of law into being.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the situation of Senator Tate who just left the chamber. He is a professor of law. He is most experienced in these matters, apparently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you are. Don't tell us what he is.
—Order! Senator Grimes, the Chair has been remarkably patient with your curiosity about the previous occupations of certain members of this chamber. That patience will not last much longer.
—Senator Tate is also Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. If it is reasonable for Senator Messner to point out clearly the previous occupation of the previous speaker, surely it is reasonable for me to ask the previous occupation of Senator Messner. If he is coy about his occupation let him be coy about it, but let him not cast aspersions on the occupation of the previous speaker.
—There is no point of order.

—By no means was I casting aspersions upon Senator Tate. In fact I was praising him for the very high position that he had gained and for the recognition he had gained from his colleagues in the law. That is the point I make. He is Chairman of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. What did the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report in respect of this legislation? I remind the Senate that it is an all party committee; it is representative of all parties in this place. Senator Tate is its Chairman. In respect of clause 17 the Committee, in its report, referred to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . all the retrospective provisions (of C. 17) which might be regarded as trespassing on personal rights and liberties . . .
That is a clear indication--

TALK.START.PARA: —Read on.
—I will and I will come to that in a moment. Let us look at clause 21. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the Committee notes that the onus is on the person served with a notice of liability to institute a formal challenge or review, and it therefore draws the initial reversal of the evidentary burden to the attention of senators in that it might be regarded as trespassing unduly on personal rights and liberties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep reading.

—That is the end of the quote. I repeat: This is a committee of this Senate talking about this legislation which was brought down by this Government. This Opposition opposes it and agrees with the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us turn to one or two other matters which were raised by Senator Tate in his brief address. He struggled manfully to try to defend the Government on this most heinous piece of legislation, I regret to say without success. However he did refer to the hardship provisions in section 265 of the income tax law. Notwithstanding that Senator Tate is a remarkable lawyer and has a fine understanding of the matter, he probably has had very little experience in dealing with the dealing with the Commissioner of Taxation in this area. Surely one of the areas of hardship that is of great concern is bankruptcy. I challenge the Minister to take to the Commissioner of Taxation a case which would result in bankruptcy as a result of the Commissioner's actions and see whether he can have it treated as a case of hardship. Bankruptcy is no defence of hardship in trying to prove one's eligibility for special release under section 265. I would like him to try it and see how far he gets. For Senator Tate to say to us that there is some let out for people who are caught in a situation such as that, by applying under section 265, is sheer rubbish.

We shall turn to other matters in this legislation. There are some clear examples of situations which have arisen by virtue of this legislation and which cut clearly across the general principles of the taxation law. There is, of course, the point that there are accumulated profits in a company. By virtue of this legislation, irrespective of the length of time that those profits have accumulated-I put to Government senators who are smiling and who seem to think that this is a great joke-full taxation has been paid on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense. You know that.

—I regret to say that Senator Grimes does not know what he is talking about. If he listens for a moment he may learn something. I repeat for Senator Grimes's education that these are profits upon which full taxation has been paid. In addition to that, companies do from time to time accumulate capital profits which result either from realised gains or perhaps from the revaluation of assets. Of course, other opportunities exist within the commercial arena. But those two groups of profits by virtue of this legislation are now brought together and treated as one in such a way as they are deemed to be fully taxable in the hands of the owner-vendors.
—So, if we pull out capital tax it's okay, is it? Is that what you are saying?

—If Senator Grimes would only listen perhaps he might understand the point I am trying to make. We are not talking about one class of profits or another; what we are talking about is the accumulated capital, be it from after tax paid profits, capital gains or otherwise, which have accumulated in a company and which, of course, represents that company's total capital.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us just for one moment consider what the capital of a company is. Some people would have us believe-I am sure that many honourable senators opposite would believe-that it is a big lump of cash sitting somewhere in a bank account or in some readily realisable asset. But what is it? That capital is represented by the total assets of a business less its liabilities. Those assets could be anything coming from the firm's plant and equipment or from the real estate that it owns upon which it operates its business. It could represent the debts owed to it by the people to whom it has sold goods on credit. It could represent money that is held in bank accounts and does, of course take into account, as offsets to that, money owed to various creditors, to bankers and to long term debenture holders. So we have a situation in which that business exists only because that capital, made up of accumulated after tax paid profits of the company and capital gains are invested in the operation of that business.

The people who earn their salaries and wages each week by working for that company are the employees of that company. They depend for their very jobs on the maintenance of the capital of that company. What is this Government proposing? It is proposing, firstly, to apply a tax to both the accumulated after tax profits and the capital profits of the company in such a way as to strip that capital entirely and to leave it in a destitute, if not bankrupt, situation. What would be the consequence of that for all of the employees of that company? Clearly there would be only one consequence. Clearly the business would have to reduce its activities. Clearly, the people employed by it would have to be disemployed and sent on to the scrap heap.

The Government came to power on 5 March promising the people 500,000 jobs in the next three years. The first thing it has done has been to set about destroying the jobs of Australians by virtue of this kind of activity. This is not the first occasion on which the Government has sought to do that. It has sought to do it in many other ways, particularly in my State. Senator Elstob had better note the wrath of the voters of South Australia in respect of what this Government has done in the uranium mining area and also, of course, in respect of the construction of the railway between Alice Springs and Darwin. Those points would lead one to believe that this Government has its sails set clearly for the destruction of the Australian economy. Why else would it put up this legislation? Is it just an Aunt Sally for the Opposition to knock down? Does the Government think we are so stupid--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is to stop tax dodgers once and for all. You have never stopped or attempted to stop tax dodgers.
—Oh, do not come on with that rubbish. Let us just have a look at what some of the media are saying. Let us consider what was said in the editorial in the Melbourne Age last Friday:

SPEECH.PARA: Retrospective legislation is acceptable when used to recover tax that has been fraudulently evaded.
I intervene to make the point that that is precisely what the Fraser Government' s legislation was aimed at doing last October when the Senate passed the legislation. The Age went on to say:
It can also be justified after a general warning has been given that tax might be collected retrospectively in the case of blatant artificial, but apparently lawful, avoidance schemes.

I intervene again to make the point that in 1978 the Parliament passed legislation which may have been regarded as retrospective in respect of the Curran scheme. I remind Senator Grimes that that traced itself back directly to activities and announcements made by the then Treasurer of the Labor Government in 1974, Mr Frank Crean. So it fits that circumstance. The Age continues:
The new legislation drives the thin edge of the retrospectivity wedge beyond its legitimate target. It is too broad: It would hit some people unfairly. It should, therefore, be modified.
The article went on to support the Coalition's attitude and made the following point:
The coalition parties are opposed to this extension on the ground that it imposes additional tax which would not have been payable at the time. Their objections have validity.

I rest my case. This is clearly the situation that we are in at present. That is why we are opposing this legislation so determinately and so clearly. Let us consider some of the problems that will arise out of this legislation. I refer to accumulated profits upon which tax has been paid. This tax will apply to that group of profits in addition to the current year's profits which were the subject of the previous legislation introduced by the Fraser Government. This means a tax upon the retention allowance which a private company can retain without incurring any tax liability. The retention allowance crystallises undistributed profits. The concept of a retention allowance is to provide liquidity for business-small business, large business, funds for development and funds in order to create jobs for Australians. The accumulated profits or retained earnings would be taxed only if they were distributed to shareholders or the company was liquidated. In other words, by embarking on schemes, as taxpayers they did not evade tax on their profits; the tax would not have been payable. But because their activities would have been perfectly legal there was no evasion.

The tax on capital profits is a similar situation. There is no evasion, there is an accumulation of capital profits in a company. Had there been no change to the company situation, the profits would never have been distributed. But this Government seeks to tax those profits as though they have been and to apply a punitive tax against not only the owners of the business in the final analysis, the shareholders of the company, the directors or the more highly paid people but also against the employees of that company and put them on the scrap-heap. This is what the legislation is about and why we on this side so vehemently oppose it.

Let us just consider a company that may have started some 50 years ago. It may have accumulated profits from its retention allowance, legally allowed under the income tax legislation, only after profits have borne their full share of primary company taxation and upon which dividends have been declared in accordance with the law and which, it turn, have borne tax in the hands of the shareholders-a perfectly legitimate and ordinary situation. Let us look at that company, say, 50 years later after its shares have been sold to an incoming businessman who purchased them in order, perhaps, to rearrange the management of the business, improve its performance, improve its profitability and employ more Australians. One could imagine that, after that period, very substantial reserves would have been built up in the company.

Let us say that the new person coming in, having purchased those shares, builds up the business over the next five years, changes its mode of operation, creates more jobs, thereby getting the company into a stronger position and resells those shares to somebody who makes an appropriate offer. Suppose that is done-as is the normal case-with a full knowledge and understanding of an arms length transaction of this kind and in a normal, business way and the shares in that company finally end up in the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. That shareholder, entrepreneur or new businessman who held the shares for five years of the total period of existence of the company of some 55 years would be required and liable , under this legislation, to pay the tax assessed by the Government's punitive legislation on the whole of the accumulated profits that have been put together over a period of 55 years, not just the five years that he owned the shares. If anything would lead shareholders to bankruptcy it is that kind of confiscatory tax. How can that be justified by Senator Tate, a professor of law from the University of Tasmania? How can it be defended by Senator Walsh?

I just wind up by making this legislation as clear to the community as it is to the Opposition. I believe that most honourable senators would know that Mr Michael Sharpe, President of the Institute of Chartered Accountants, a body of which I am a member-I declare that interest-noted the equity of the proposal in a telex to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as follows:

This Bill proposes that vendor shareholders pay tax on already taxed accumulated profits which the company had no obligation to distribute and which, in ordinary circumstances, would have been retained. One result of this Bill will be the forced and unnecessary winding-up of long-established family businesses which rely on retained earnings to finance their ongoing business operations. Such a penalty is unfair.

That comes from one of the leading professional organisations in this country whch cannot be criticised in any way for having a role in supporting tax evasion and avoidance methods. I hope that all honourable senators will recognise that in 1979 the Institute of Chartered Accountants was one of the first as a public body interested in issues of this kind to take a public stand against artificial and contrived tax avoidance schemes. In fact it issued directives to its members , including me, not to involve themselves in that kind of transaction.

These Bills constitute a savage attack on the Australian private sector. They are vindictive, vengeful and, of course, confiscatory. They owe their origin to this Government's obsessive belief that all people engaging in private commerce are dishonest. This obsession has, in this instance, clearly blinded the Government. Clearly, it has blinded the eyes of the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, as no doubt honourable senators on the other side of the chamber are aware. But in case they are not I draw to their attention a Press release which I think was issued late this evening which reads as follows:
The Government remains committed to its legislation to recoup the many millions of dollars in tax which are owed from blatant tax avoidance schemes.
We believe strongly that the legislation should be passed by the Senate unamended.
At the request of Senators Mason, Evans and Harradine, I authorised access for them to the Taxation Office.
The Taxation Office, as a result of their request, has advised them about the terms of possible amendments to the bill.
Mr Dawkins then goes on to say:
My assistance was made as a matter of courtesy--
And, get this-
and with no intention of supporting or encouraging any amendment of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate didn't know that.

—Of course, Senator Tate did not know that and he was up here preaching to us a little earlier about the good intentions of this Government. This Government has taken into its confidence, apparently with a thoroughly, I would say, honourable attitude, as it evidenced, to speak to honourable senators on this side of the House and allow them access to the staff of the Australian Taxation Office. It has advised them about possible amendments, and then it has the gall to say: 'It does not matter what you think. We will not amend the law anyway. We want it'. That is what this Government is all about. It is a jack- boot government and it wants to ride over the rights of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am the first speaker in this debate who voted against the legislation last year. On a brief count I did a little while ago, I think there are now only nine honourable senators who will be in that position when the vote on the second reading of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill is taken. The situation that I wish to put is in two parts. The first part deals with the principle of retrospectivity, the second part deals with this Bill in particular. I wish to reiterate some of the points that I raised last year and if Senator Button wishes to interject, I will be able to give my references to the points he raises. The points that I raised in terms of the retrospective principle last year apply equally in this particular piece of legislation. In the Age this morning the stance that I am taking was called a reliance on a simplistic principle. I do not happen to believe that it is a simplistic principle. It is a principle which is enshrined in the United Nations International Covenant on Human Rights. It is a principle which is contained in the United States Bill on human rights. While other honourable senators may not agree with the principle, I do not believe, in any shape or form, that it is a simplistic one. I believe it is an important one. It is one which I would have hoped might be enshrined in any Bill of rights that this country enacts. What is at stake is a situation that, to me, is extremely important; that is, that when a person engages in any activity, I believe that he has a human right to know whether that activity is legal or otherwise. That cannot result if retropective legislation is carried out. It is not possible to know, as one enters into an activity of whatever kind, whether at some later stage that activity may be declared illegal. That is the crux of the problem that I have with this legislation and with the legislation introduced by the Liberal and National parties last year.
—Hear, hear! So did I.

—Yes, I acknowledge that. I wish to make the point that last year's legislation dealt with a number of activities which undoubtedly were fraudulent. I do not think that anyone in this chamber stood up in the debate last year-I have re-read it briefly-and actually claimed that that was not the case. I think everybody in this chamber and in this country is very much aware that there have been rip-offs in the taxation system. But if that is the case, the Commissioner of Taxation still retains the power to go back to 1972 and take those people into court.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I made last year was that it is not a matter of democratic right to stand up in this place or any other place in this country and say: 'You are guilty'. It is a requirement of any just legal system that a person not only be able to say that someone is guilty but also be willing to take that person to the court and prove that he is guilty before his peers or a judge. I believe that is basic to any democratic operation.

Those fundamental principles were violated last year in that the Government could have instructed the Commissioner of Taxation to inquire into and take to court many of the people involved in the activities that were taking place. On the best legal advice that we have available to us, it was clear that those cases would have succeeded. Those people would have been caught by legal action and would have been made to pay. That action would have been supported by every person in this country. But to go beyond that and to violate that basic principle is to engage in an activity which ought not to happen in a democratic community-certainly not in one dedicated to notions of human rights and a legal system such as are current in this country. It is always possible to say: 'We could recoup this tax or that tax it we engage particular laws. We could gain this amount of revenue or that amount of revenue if we change laws retrospectively.' There is a very simple retrospective law which would recoup far more than the Government has attempted to under this legislation. We could rule illegal all deductions on income tax back to 1972. Why not? The reason is that that would also violate the principle.

That brings me to another point. Is what will happen with the passage of this legislation a right which was given under the law? The Government cannot have it both ways. If it is a right given under law then the people are immune. If it is not a right under the law, they are liable to prosecution. There are no other positions. It is one or the other. If we are not willing to go into court and launch prosecutions against individuals on the basis that we believe that what they did was fraudulent, then we stand condemned, not those people.

What enabled us to get to this position, and what enables the present Government to bring in this legislation, was the legislation which was introduced into this place last year by the Liberal-National Party Government. It was that Government-I exclude honourable senators from the Liberal and National parties who voted against the legislation; I am sure they will register their points of view, which has been registered in Hansard-that started this off . It broke that principle which enabled this Government to go much further than it would have dared to go if that legislation had not been passed in November last year. That has to be accepted. Now the Government is quite happy, for the sake of revenue, to violate basic legal, constitutional and human rights in this country.

I was vastly disappointed by the contribution from Senator Tate. As a supporting argument for actually engaging in this particular operation, he said that if we did not do so we would have to raise taxes. It seems to me to be the very basest of arguments to say that we are happy to hit people, whether or not they are entitled to be hit, on the basis that we do not want to put a fair tax on everybody. I acknowledge that this particular view has been prevalent in the electorate. The stand I am taking is not the popular stand by any means. It is a complicated issue and people are not willing to go down the track and find out about it. The Government will not suffer any electoral backlash by pushing this legislation. It is a popular issue on the side of the Government. I acknowledge that. But that does not make it right. I have heard Senator Tate argue that point in here time and again. I was extremely disappointed that he stood up here tonight to use that argument as his reason for supporting the legislation. If he believes the legislation is correct it stands on its own merits. But surely we should not do this because otherwise we would have to put a tax on everybody. That does not make this piece of legislation right. That surely is the basest of arguments to propose.

So we have said to people: 'We now have to declare wrong what you did at some stage in the past. We want to rewrite history from the side of the Government'. Would the Government believe it would be legitimate for those people now to ask: 'If that is now to be the consequence, may I have leave to rearrange my affairs to meet your new law'? Would that not also be fair? What would those people do in those circumstances under this law? Of course, they would retract those types of operations. That would seem to me to be a fair and reasonable proposition. If one side of the compact is allowed to rewrite history, surely the other side of the compact ought also to be allowed. That is basically the absurdity of retrospective legislation-that we declare on one side what people did was wrong, and they stay with it. We say: 'We are going to penalise you for an activity you did in the past and you may not rewrite that piece of history'.

Basically this legislation imposes a penalty tax on all past profits accumulated over the entire life of a company, upon which a minimum tax of 55c in the dollar has already been paid. That is, it will put a tax on all past trading profits. It may catch up companies. Presumably all senators have received representations on this and have looked at some of the cases. Some companies go back to the last century; we are not just talking about companies that started in 1972. We are talking about legitimate operations since before this Parliament was formed. That is the extent of this piece of legislation, but it goes further. All past reserves accumulated over the entire life of a company which under normal commercial circumstances would never attract taxation-that is , past capital profits-will be caught up. In other words, the Government is now proposing a new tax on items which would never have been taxed even if the operation that the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) spoke about had indeed been carried out. Worse than that, we then find there is a 60 per cent penalty tax on things such as goodwill, credit reserves and book entries between associated and related companies.

Let us be very clear that this Bill covers both wet and dry Slutzkin schemes, so-called. The Taxation Office has acknowledged that. This means that we may refer to the judgment of the High Court of Australia in relation to this legislation. In passing, it is interesting to note that Mr Slutzkin is now held out to be a criminal when in fact he was the gentleman who took his own company to the highest court in this land and won a judgment. He is now bandied around in the community as being a criminal. His name is synonymous with the criminal activities of bottom-of-the-harbour companies when in fact he was the person who won a High Court case on the law as it stood. I think that needs to be taken into consideration when we are looking at this matter. That shows how far this legislation is reaching.

The Minister for Finance in his second reading speech in the House of Representatives said that, if the operations of the companies were carried out in such a way that the companies continued to operate as going concerns, the dividends in the hands of the shareholders would have been taxable. The Bill deems a dividend to have been paid and accordingly imposes a tax. It seems to me that this is where the fundamental area of commercial logic lies. I refer to the factor I have already mentioned. If the companies had continued to operate as going concerns, it is highly improbable that any greater dividend would have been declared than was necessary under Division 7 or, depending on the type of company involved, possibly was necessary to appease shareholders. In other words , if we construct a hypothetical scenario of commercial operation and then propose to tax in relation to that hypothetical scenario, we ought also, I believe, to look at that scenario to see whether it holds up in commercial practice. Of course, it would not.

Another aspect I wish to look at has been overlooked in the debate so far. This piece of legislation will not touch the really big people because our law will not reach them. They did not engage in activities in Australia; they went overseas. They went to the Bahamas or some other place to engage in their activities. Basically, we are looking at small and medium sized businesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Mr Dawkins said, 90 per cent of them were small company businesses.

—We are looking at small and medium sized businesses. The bulk of that group is extremely important to our economic health. That is not only my opinion. It happens to be that of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) also. If we look at the Australian Labor Party's policy speech, we find a commitment by the Labor Party to small businesses. It proposed an increase in respect of after tax trading profits from 80 per cent to 100 per cent for small businesses where retained earnings will be used within the company's business for 'genuine business purposes'. That is precisely the problem that occurs with most of the restructuring companies that are caught up under this tax. They are the ones that are restructured to retain that money.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister explained this proposal by his party. I supported him and thought it was one of the best policies that had come out on small business in the election campaign. I gave credit where credit was due. It shows that if what was proposed was done it would give probably the best boost to be imagined to small business in this country. That proposal is the best way of doing it. The Prime Minister acknowledged that fact and said that was why the Labor Party was committed to that action. What it is doing in this legislation with these companies is the very opposite to the election proposal. These companies, at the time they took the action in question, did so using lawful methods. The Government now proposes to penalise them for that action. That point has not been raised so far. But it is an absurdity in terms of what the Labor Party committed itself to do for small business if it was elected.

I believe it is important to realise also that we are not talking about merely corporate entities. It is all very well to sit here and to vote one way or another on this issue and not feel a great sense of responsibility. But we are talking about the entire livelihoods of people, their families and their employees. A group of 16 companies that met in Canberra a few days ago tallied up the employment loss if this provision were introduced. That group stated that 19,500 would lose jobs in these 16 small companies. If this example is spread throughout the nation, what are the employment implications? I hope that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) in his reply at the end of the second reading debate will be able to give us the Government's projections of the employment losses as a result of this legislation. I am sure that the Government has indeed undertaken that activity.

But we must consider more than the employment losses. When we destroy companies , we destroy company tax. We destroy income tax from the employees and increase social security payments in not only that company but also downstream companies. The spreading effect also has to be estimated. I believe that while the Government may come out ahead in the first financial year I am quite sure that the books three years hence will show it to be in the red from this operation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us set the record straight once and for all regarding the Commonwealth Grants Commission's recommendations for the Territory. As I have indicated before, the Grants Commission is an independent authority that reviews the requirements of funding of States and Territories. I would say that the Grants Commission is a fair authority. The Northern Territory Government receives $3, 035 per head of population to provide standard government services, compared with $926 per head of population in New South Wales and Victoria. In addition, as a result of small population and large distances-there is a clause within the memorandum of understanding that in remote areas such as the Territory there can be a special grant-the Grants Commission recommended a special assistance grant of $98 per head. Having in mind the necessity for developing the north, which has been ignored over the years, there is provision for a recurrent grant. The Grants Commission recommended Commonwealth assistance of $2,574 per head merely to keep the Northern Territory on par with the States. Clearly, it is not a voracious appetite. It is a grant to maintain the standard of living that all other States enjoy. I believe very clearly that the people of the north-the people of the outback, including those in the Northern Territory-have some right to have a parity of living standards. So under the circumstances the Northern Territory should not be attacked or punished for this situation, which appears to be the case.
The other allegations made by Senator Walsh were based on his approach of smearing. He said that accounting firms in Darwin were involved in wide scale tax evasion. He stated:

Just let me tell you about the so called tax avoidance that the Territory assists by having a lower stamp duty than elsewhere.

Each State and the Territory, Mr Speaker, has the right to set its own level of stamp duty on instruments evidencing commercial transactions. The States have, in respect of share transactions, applied a uniform level of duty for many years . In the Territory there was no duty at all prior to self-government under Commonwealth administration. We have introduced such a duty but, in the absence of locally listed companies and to keep the administrative costs of our small tax office down to a reasonable level, applied it at a relatively low level and at a flat rate.

If we had to create a share valuation capacity in the same way as the States, a very sophisticated bureaucratic structure would be required. This is not warranted in our circumstances. The cost of collection would have exceeded the returns.
For these reasons it's not true to say that the lower level of duty in the Territory inflated our demand for residual Commonwealth funding.

Higher rates of duty in the States did make it profitable for certain share transactions to be carried out in the Northern Territory rather than in the States where the company to which the shares related was situated.
The so-called 'Darwin shuffle' was the means adopted by many such companies to avoid payment of duty in their home State.

The mechanics of the scheme involved the opening of a branch share register in the Northern Territory. When shares were to be transfered, the transaction would be registered in the Darwin register: Northern Territory stamp duty would be paid, and the register closed and returned to the relevant State. Duty was not payable in the home State because the liable instrument was at no relevant time in the home State. Stamp duty being a tax on instruments requires an instrument in the jurisdiction at the relevant time to attract the tax.

It was the State, not the Commonwealth, tax base which was eroded each time such a branch register was opened and used in this way. Each State had the power to stop the practice-simply by declaring transactions or branch registers of companies incorporated in their State to be liable to duty as though the transaction had been processed through the principal register.
All States have now legislated in this way and the practice has ceased.

The Territory has co-operated with the States in ensuring that avoidance by choice of jurisdiction is minimised. The Treasurer met with the Commonwealth Treasurer and the Treasurers of all States last year and subscribed to a joint approach for common action to combat this and other forms of avoidance. It is expected that more detailed plans for translation of this accord into State and Commonwealth legislation will be formulated at further meetings to be held later this year.

. . . and of course, Mr Speaker, the honourable the Senator the Minister in the Senate for Resources and Energy too was inferring that the Northern Territory is generously funded-is over-funded-is embarrassed by funding from the Commonwealth , to use the Leader of the Opposition's words, and I can't do better than to read into the record, Mr Speaker, the letter I handed the Prime Minister last Friday.
