During my visit to Canberra last Friday to see the Prime Minister regarding the railway I sought an appointment with the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, and the purpose of my visit to him was to determine what progress had been made by the Commonwealth Government towards endorsing the arrangements under which the Commonwealth will continue to subsidise public electricity supply in the Territory and contribute towards the cost of the channel. I'm sure no member of this House will need to be reminded how crucial these arrangements are to the economic viability of the Territory. In broad terms users will pay $ 50 million this financial year for their electricity according to tariffs which are already amongst the highest in Australia. The subsidy from the Commonwealth will provide the remaining $58 million that the Electricity Commission needs to meet its fuel bills, other operating expenses and debt changes for the year.

It takes no great skill in arithmetic to work out that without the Commonwealth subsidy electricity consumers would be paying more than double the amount they are at present. This comes about because we're isolated and dispersed across one sixth of Australia, compounded by the fact that we were lumbered at self government with an expensive unreliable oil fired power system to meet our needs . In recognition of those inescapable facts the memorandum of understanding provided for an ongoing subsidy, together with Commonwalth funding assistance towards the replacement of Stokes Hill by a coal-fired station.
The memorandum specified that, following some years of interim subsidy arrangements and identification of the replacement power station, more permanent arrangements would be put in place.
That is what we negotiated with the Commonwealth Government last year.

I regret to advise the House that I came away from last week's meeting with Senator Walsh with the gravest apprehension that this could be yet another area in which the new Commonwealth Government is preparing to welch on a firm commitment to Territorians.
The now-familiar signs are there.
In a letter of 17 May this year acknowledging a recent reminder letter from me, Senator Walsh stated that (and I quote):
'Cabinet will be reviewing the proposals made to you by the former Government'.
Senator Walsh knows full well that negotiations with the former Government had gone far beyond the stage of unilateral Commonwealth proposals by the time of the Federal election.
Indeed, all essential principles were agreed between Mr Fraser and myself here in Darwin almost a year ago.
Let there be no illusions about the existence of an agreement long before the Hawke Government came to power.
On 16 March 1982, Mr Fraser began his letter to me in the following terms: (and I quote)

'I am pleased to advise you that decisions have been taken to assist the Northern Territory in the funding of the proposed coal-fired power station and in providing continuing subsidy support for the operations of the Northern Territory Electricity Commission in the period to 1986-87.'

We differed on a couple of aspects of the arrangements as proposed and, after further consideration, the Prime Minister wrote to me again on 29 June 1982 modifying his proposal in a fashion acceptable to both Governments.
He concluded his letter as follows: (and I quote again)
'Subject to your concurrence with these conditions, I propose that Sir John Carrick and Mr Perron finalise the terms of a Ministerial agreement covering the electricity subsidy arrangements'.
I provided my concurrence (by letter) on 30 June 1982.

Only the fine detail of the formula and administrative arrangements then remained to be settled between officers of the two Governments. Most were in place, I am advised, by early November and the last was settled in February, and Mr Speaker they've been paying us the subsidy in accordance with those arrangements since the Hawke Government came to power.

The Treasurer, Mr Perron, approved the detailed formula and administrative arrangements on 17 February and wrote immediately to Senator Carrick suggesting that he formally endorse them, thus concluding the process agreed between the Chief Minister and Prime Minister.
The Federal Election intervened before that formality took place.

Despite all the correspondence, Ministerial meetings and confirmation repeatedly provided, the new Minister has chosen to put the arrangements up for grabs as if no agreement existed. He has done this, as I understand it, solely on the grounds that the Commonwealth Government has a big deficit problem in the coming financial year.
Honourable Members will recognise an all-too-familiar theme.

Another long-term arrangement crucial to the viability of the Northern Territory is being threatened because of the Commonwealth's immediate budgetary problems. After the tax share and capital grants, the electricity subsidy is the largest component of our Commonwealth funding. Senator Walsh assured me that some sort of subsidy would continue, but is clearly looking for a means of cutting it back as from next financial year.
I remind honourable members again, however, of the consequences if he should succeed.
Every dollar held back by the Commonwealth would have to be replaced through higher electricity tariffs.
Without the subsidy, electricity charges would be more than double what they are today. That is unthinkable.
Any tinkering with the agreed arrangements to reduce the level of subsidy would be turning a blind eye yet again to equitable and binding arrangement reached with the previous Government.
New Governments which do that within our democratic system cannot hope to retain any credibility at all.
I hope that commonsense and honour will prevail, Mr Speaker, and that my fears prove to be groundless.
Prime Minister,
I felt it was imperative that I see you, since I believe you are being misinformed about the Territory's financial capacity.
Your Government's proposal on the railway makes that clear.
Both you and Mr Keating have referred during the last week to the fact that the Territory receives five times the State average per capita, in Federal funding.
Your Treasurer stated publicly last Thursday that this funding level is very generous, and your letter to me implied that you share that belief.

The overall level of Federal assistance to the Northern Territory for recurrent purposes has been tested every year since Self-Government by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. Its most recent report, for 1980/81, determined that the Territory warranted additional assistance of $11.8 million over and above other Commonwealth grants in order to enable Territorians to receive a level and quality of services no more and no less than those enjoyed in NSW and Victoria.
It reached that judgment after surveying Territory revenue sources and calculating what could be raised by the Territory Government exerting the same revenue effort as in those States.
There is no reason to doubt that this position has changed significantly in the last two years, except that the need for supplementary Federal assistance has almost certainly grown.

The fact that our overall Federal funding is five times as great per head is because it costs that much more to treat Territorians like other Australians. You must have seen in your own visits to the Territory why this is so. Isolation , distance, diseconomies of small scale, the high proportion of aboriginals in the population . . . the list sometimes seems endless.

Your Government's requirement on railway funding could only be met, therefore, by a combination of lowering the standard and quality of NT government services to a level further below those of the southern States, just when we are starting to make progress towards achieving those standards and raising the Territory's taxation effort to a level above that of the southern States.
I despair at the difficulty I have in getting that simple fact through.
We are not overfunded-it just costs a hell of a lot more to do normal government business in the Northern Territory.
We are not undertaxing our population, because the Grants Commission procedures ensure that the Commonwealth would not contribute an additional cent to balancing our budget.
I am not prepared to tax Territorians to fund a national asset-they meet their full share already through Commonwealth taxation.
Likewise I am not prepared to sacrifice Territory schools, medical services, aboriginal essential services and other government services that Australians elsewhere enjoy.

The Northern Territory accepted self-Government only with an assurance that the Commonwealth would provide a sufficient level of financial assistance to enable State-type services to be provided by the Territory Government at a level and to a standard commensurate with the States.
This assurance was provided through the Memorandum of Understanding and supported by the extension of the purview of the Grants Commission to include the Territory.

There is consequently no need for you to accept my assurance that the Territory is not over-funded, and that it does not have the capacity to fund even part of a national railway. Ask your own independent authority-the Grants Commission. It will lay to rest once and for all the mischievous misuse of statistics regarding the Northern Territory's true financial position.

- major disabilities in that included

- Northern Territory revenue disability ($356 less $420) was $64 per head

With respect to the facilitating of tax evasion, the Northern Territory Government deliberately set lower share transfer duties. Having set those lower share transfer duties the facilities offered by the Northern Territory were widely used-as anyone who has ever searched any corporate affairs documents in search of this sort of thing would know-for temporary transfers of share registers to Darwin in the process of tax evasion. The Chief Minister must surely have noticed the enormous revenue accruing to his Government because of the extraordinary amount of share transfers being processed through Darwin as one of the steps in a chain of tax evasion activity. Surely he must have noticed the revenue that that was bringing in. The Territory, with a total population of about 130,000 people and a city with a population of about 60,000 people, had a share transfer revenue grossly disproportionate to the amount of business which would normally be expected to take place in such an area.

I give an example of a stereotype case. As I mentioned, anyone who has searched corporate affairs documents would have seen countless similar examples of this sort of transaction. Three companies were registered in Perth-the Frederic Salon , Greenbank and Stirling West companies. The principal shareholder in all of them happened to be Ransley Victor Garland. My source for this is the Corporate Affairs Office in Perth. It has all been put on the record in the Parliament before. I do not actually have the documents with me to incorporate again but I recall the case clearly. Peat Marwick Mitchell and Co., through its office in Perth, transferred the shares in these companies to its office in Darwin, where they were held for a very short period-I think a couple of days-and then transferred to Melbourne. The companies finished up in the hands of one Ian Stafford Collie, who is now in the dock facing criminal charges relating to tax evasion. I do not think I need to say any more except to repeat that the deliberate establishment by the Northern Territory Government of lower charges for share transfers for the purpose of attracting revenue to that Government facilitated widespread tax evasion.

In respect of the status of the Burdekin project, the matter raised by Senator Collard, I make several points. The irresponsible supplementary water resources program of the previous Government was cancelled in the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 19 May. As an example of the degree of discipline which was applied to the selection of projects by the previous Government, the program included $5m for a feasibility study of the Bradfield scheme. It was hailed by the then Prime Minister as another Snowy scheme. Without going into the economics of it, I make just one point: The simple fact is that in the Snowy scheme the water descends about 400 metres and generates large amounts of electricity but in the Bradfield scheme it had to be pumped uphill about the same distance and would have consumed enormous amounts of electricity, so much so that, according to the report of Cameron, McNamara and Partners, the annual cost of pumping per irrigated hectare on the other side of the Great Divide would be $1,500. That was hailed by the then Prime Minister as another Snowy scheme. The Burdekin project was never part of that supplementary water resources program and it is still under review. I expect a submission on this matter to go to Cabinet shortly.
In respect of Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines, I have no direct knowledge of the matters raised but I will endeavour to obtain an answer from the relevant Minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
